results.46567:
This case was filed on May 5, 2025, in the United States District Court for the District of Rhode Island by a Venezuelan national detained at the Wyatt Detention Facility. The petitioner, represented by private attorneys and the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), seeks a writ of habeas corpus and injunctive relief, challenging his imminent removal from the United States under a presidential proclamation invoking the Alien Enemies Act (AEA), 50 U.S.C. §§ 21–24. The respondents are federal executive officials and departments, including the President (in his official capacity), Attorney General, Secretaries of Homeland Security, State, and Defense, as well as regional and facility-level immigration officials.

The petitioner claims that the President’s March 14, 2025, Proclamation unlawfully invokes the AEA to authorize the summary removal of certain Venezuelan nationals alleged to be members of the Tren de Aragua (TdA) gang. The Proclamation designates these individuals as “alien enemies” and permits their immediate removal—without the procedural protections typically afforded under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), Convention Against Torture (CAT), or due process. The petitioner argues that the AEA only applies in times of declared war or actual military invasion by a foreign nation or government, neither of which, he asserts, exist with respect to Venezuela or the TdA. The petitioner denies any gang affiliation and claims he is at risk of summary removal based on unreliable identification criteria such as tattoos. He has a pending asylum application and fears persecution or torture if removed to El Salvador or Venezuela.

The petitioner seeks a temporary restraining order (TRO) to prevent his removal while the case is pending, as well as declaratory and injunctive relief prohibiting application of the Proclamation to him without adequate notice and an opportunity to respond. The asserted causes of action include violations of the AEA, INA, CAT, and the Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause, as well as the Suspension Clause.

Judge Melissa R. DuBose is presiding over the matter. On the day of filing, the court issued an order requiring at least 48 hours’ advance notice before the petitioner could be moved outside Rhode Island. This was later amended to require 72 business hours’ advance notice to the court and the petitioner before any such transfer. The court has not ruled on the ultimate merits or issued a final injunction as of the latest docket entries.

The case is part of a broader context of nationwide litigation challenging the same Proclamation. Several federal courts (including in D.C., Texas, Colorado, and New York) have issued preliminary or permanent injunctions against similar removals, finding likely statutory and constitutional violations. Notable reported opinions cited include J.G.G. v. Trump, 2025 WL 825115; J.A.V. v. Trump, 2025 WL 1257450; D.B.U. v. Trump, 2025 WL 1163530; and G.F.F. v. Trump, 2025 WL 1166480.

The underlying factual basis includes evidence that individuals have been removed under the Proclamation without meaningful notice or opportunity to contest their designation as gang members, sometimes based on questionable criteria. At least 137 Venezuelans were sent to a Salvadoran prison under these procedures, and reports suggest many had no connection to TdA. The petitioner specifically alleges he was denied a bond hearing and identified as a TdA member without opportunity to testify, based solely on physical characteristics.

To date, the court’s orders have preserved the petitioner’s presence in Rhode Island pending further proceedings, but no trial or final judgment has occurred, and there is no record of settlement, appeals, or court-appointed monitoring. The case continues as part of broader national litigation over the scope of executive authority under the Alien Enemies Act and attendant due process protections.
results.46582:
On April 30, 2025, a habeas corpus petition and complaint for declaratory and injunctive relief was filed in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas by a Palestinian woman residing in the United States since 2016. The petitioner, represented by private counsel and advocacy organizations including the Texas Civil Rights Project, Southern Poverty Law Center, CUNY School of Law, and Muslim Advocates, challenges her ongoing detention by federal immigration authorities.

The petitioner had lawfully entered the United States on a tourist visa and later became a student in New Jersey, maintaining lawful status until 2022, when she withdrew from her student visa program based on erroneous advice. While living in New Jersey, she attended peaceful demonstrations supporting Palestinian rights, including an April 2024 protest near Columbia University. She was arrested at the protest for a local ordinance violation, but the charges were promptly dismissed.

In March 2025, following a series of executive orders and policies issued by President Trump targeting noncitizens perceived as supporting Palestinian rights, federal agents investigated the petitioner, focusing on her protest activities and a single monetary transfer to a family member in Palestine. Despite finding no evidence of national security violations, Department of Homeland Security (DHS) agents detained her after a voluntary interview, transferred her over 1,500 miles from her home to the Prairieland Detention Facility in Texas, and publicly accused her of supporting terrorism without substantiation.

An immigration judge found that the petitioner was neither a danger to the community nor a flight risk and granted her release on a $20,000 bond on April 3, 2025. Nonetheless, DHS exercised its regulatory authority to appeal and automatically stay her release, resulting in her continued detention without further judicial review for up to 130 days. The petitioner alleges that this continued confinement is in retaliation for her protected speech and association, in violation of her First Amendment rights, and that the procedures applied to her, including the automatic stay, violate her Fifth Amendment rights to procedural and substantive due process.

The petitioner further claims that her confinement at the Prairieland Detention Facility has resulted in severe deprivations, including overcrowded and unsanitary conditions, denial of adequate medical care, and, critically, ongoing violations of her religious freedom. As a practicing Muslim, she alleges she has been denied halal meals, appropriate accommodations for prayer, and modest clothing by the facility’s warden and ICE field office director, in violation of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA), 42 U.S.C. § 2000bb-1.

The legal foundation for her claims includes habeas relief under 28 U.S.C. § 2241, the First and Fifth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution, and RFRA. The remedies sought are her immediate release from detention, declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent further violations of her constitutional and statutory rights, and court orders prohibiting future re-detention absent specific procedural safeguards.

The case is presided over by Judge Rebecca Rutherford, Magistrate Judge, with oversight from District Judge Sam A. Lindsay. Significant filings include a motion for preliminary injunction seeking release pending judgment, which was heard on June 5, 2025, with the petitioner participating remotely. On June 27, 2025, the magistrate judge recommended that the petitioner be immediately released from detention pending final judgment, a recommendation that remains pending before the district judge following objections from both parties.

There are no consolidated or directly related cases in this court, but the complaint references parallel enforcement actions and similar challenges brought by other noncitizens detained or targeted under the same executive orders. No trial has been held to date, and the case is ongoing.

The petitioner’s confinement arises from the federal government’s new policy targeting noncitizens for immigration enforcement based on their perceived support for Palestinian rights, with the government relying on protest participation and protected association as grounds for adverse action. The petitioner alleges that, in her case, these actions have led to unlawful and retaliatory detention and severe violations of her religious and constitutional rights.
results.46496:
On April 24, 2025, three nonprofit organizations—Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights, Southern Border Communities Coalition, and Urban Justice Center—filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem. The plaintiffs, represented by private and advocacy counsel (including Public Citizen and Democracy Forward Foundation), challenge DHS’s March 21, 2025, decision to close three internal oversight offices: the Office for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties (CRCL), the Office of the Citizenship and Immigration Services Ombudsman (CIS Ombudsman Office), and the Office of the Immigration Detention Ombudsman (OIDO).

The plaintiffs, all organizations that regularly interact with these oversight offices on behalf of their members or clients, allege that the closure was abrupt and total. Nearly all employees of the three offices were placed on administrative leave and issued reduction-in-force notices with separation dates of May 23, 2025. The government instructed employees not to perform any official duties, including processing pending complaints or transferring cases. Congressional appropriations for these offices for fiscal year 2024 remained in place at the time of closure.

The plaintiffs bring their action under the Constitution and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), alleging that the elimination of the oversight offices was ultra vires and violated Congress’s statutory directives. Specifically, the plaintiffs assert that Congress mandated the existence and functioning of these offices through various provisions in the Homeland Security Act of 2002 (6 U.S.C. §§ 345, 272, and 205) and related appropriations. The plaintiffs also claim that the shutdown was arbitrary and capricious under the APA (5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A)), exceeded statutory authority (5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(C)), violated the constitutional separation of powers, and flouted the Impoundment Control Act and Anti-Deficiency Act.

The remedy sought is declaratory and injunctive relief, specifically an order requiring DHS to restore the CRCL, CIS Ombudsman, and OIDO offices, reinstate employees and contractors necessary to carry out their statutory functions, resume complaint processing, and refrain from further actions impeding the offices’ operations.

Judge Ana C. Reyes presides over the matter. The case does not involve class action plaintiffs, consolidated, or directly related cases, though the plaintiffs’ advocacy is tied to other ongoing litigation and administrative oversight efforts.

Plaintiffs filed motions for a preliminary injunction and a temporary restraining order to halt the dissolution and require immediate reinstatement of the offices’ functions. Evidentiary hearings and status conferences were held in May and June 2025, during which the government contended that it was taking steps to re-staff the offices and resume statutory functions, while plaintiffs disputed the effectiveness and good faith of these efforts. The record contains references to ongoing disputes over the government’s hiring process, budgetary statements suggesting possible elimination of OIDO, and the lack of adequate staff to perform statutory functions.

As of July 2025, the Court has not issued a final ruling on the merits or entered a decree. The preliminary injunction motion was denied as moot following a joint motion for expedited discovery and summary judgment briefing, and the case is proceeding toward dispositive motions. No settlement or consent decree has been reached, and there is no court-appointed monitor or reported opinions to date.

The factual basis of the case centers on the plaintiffs’ regular use of DHS oversight offices to address civil rights, immigration, and detention-related complaints, and their asserted harm from losing these avenues for redress. Plaintiffs allege that the closures have impeded their ability to advocate for clients, forced them to use less effective or more burdensome alternatives, and undermined congressional oversight of DHS activities.

The case remains pending, with summary judgment briefing scheduled and ongoing disputes regarding the restoration and future funding of the oversight offices.
results.46432:
This case was filed on April 18, 2025, in the United States District Court for the District of Minnesota by a Bangladeshi national who was a 20-year-old student lawfully enrolled at Minnesota State University, Mankato, on an F-1 visa. The petitioner was represented by private counsel from Fredrikson & Byron, the American Civil Liberties Union of Minnesota, The Advocates for Human Rights, and the University of Minnesota Detainee Rights Clinic. The respondents were federal and local officials responsible for immigration enforcement and detention, including the President of the United States, the Attorney General, senior officials from the Department of Homeland Security and Immigration and Customs Enforcement, the Secretary of State, and local county officials.

The petitioner challenged his continued detention by federal immigration authorities after being arrested on March 28, 2025, following the purported revocation of his visa and termination of his SEVIS (Student and Exchange Visitor Information System) record. At the time of his arrest, he was in good academic standing and had no disqualifying immigration violations. The government initially cited failure to maintain status and later invoked visa revocation and public safety rationales. The petitioner alleged that his enforcement was not based on any legitimate immigration violation but was in retaliation for his public speech, particularly his advocacy for Palestinian human rights on social media. He claimed his arrest was part of a broader campaign targeting international students for their political expression.

The legal claims were brought under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 (habeas corpus), alleging violations of the First Amendment (free speech), Fifth Amendment (due process), and the Administrative Procedure Act. The petitioner sought immediate release, declaratory and injunctive relief, and a halt to any transfer or removal from the district pending adjudication.

After the petitioner was ordered released on bond by an Immigration Judge, federal authorities invoked an automatic administrative stay, preventing his release without individualized findings of danger or flight risk. The petitioner’s subsequent requests for emergency relief resulted in a temporary restraining order on April 22, 2025, by Judge Jerry W. Blackwell, barring his removal or transfer from the district. The TRO was repeatedly extended through June 17, 2025, for good cause, to preserve the court’s jurisdiction and prevent irreparable harm.

On May 5, 2025, Judge Blackwell granted the petitioner’s motion for release on bail pending adjudication, finding that the petitioner presented substantial constitutional claims and faced exceptional circumstances, including deteriorating medical conditions and ongoing academic harm. The court found that the government’s justification for detention shifted over time and was not supported by the evidence.

On June 17, 2025, the court granted the petition for writ of habeas corpus, concluding that the petitioner’s arrest and detention violated the First Amendment because they were motivated by protected political speech, and that the government failed to show it would have taken the same action absent that speech. The court also found violations of the Fifth Amendment due process clause, both because the detention served punitive or retaliatory purposes and because the government invoked the automatic stay provision without any individualized showing or meaningful opportunity for review. Additionally, the court determined that the termination of the petitioner’s SEVIS record was arbitrary, capricious, and not in accordance with law or agency policy, thus violating the Administrative Procedure Act. The petitioner was ordered to remain released under the original bond and conditions set by the Immigration Judge.

The final judgment was entered on June 18, 2025, granting the writ and maintaining the petitioner’s release. No trial was held, as the matter was resolved on the written record. The government appealed the decision to the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals. Judge Jerry W. Blackwell presided over all rulings. No settlement, court-appointed monitor, or disputes over settlement enforcement occurred. The case referenced but did not consolidate with several similar cases involving international students and immigration enforcement in the district. The factual basis centered on the petitioner’s protected speech, the shifting and pretextual enforcement rationale, and the lack of lawful grounds for detention.
results.46477:
This case was filed on April 14, 2025, in the United States District Court for the Western District of Michigan by a group of international students and recent graduates from public universities and vocational programs in Michigan and several other states. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel, challenged actions taken by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and its officials, including the DHS Secretary, the Acting Director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), and the Detroit ICE Field Office Director. The plaintiffs are individuals (not a certified class) whose F-1 or M-1 nonimmigrant student status records were terminated in the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS), which tracks the status of foreign students.

The plaintiffs alleged that DHS terminated their SEVIS records without valid regulatory grounds, causing immediate adverse consequences including loss of employment authorization, disruption of studies, risk of arrest or removal, and uncertainty regarding their legal status. The terminations were justified by DHS as relating to criminal records checks or visa revocations, but the plaintiffs denied any qualifying criminal convictions or immigration violations that would support loss of status under the applicable regulations. The underlying cause of action is based on the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), with the plaintiffs claiming the agency action was arbitrary, capricious, and contrary to law (5 U.S.C. § 706(2)), and also alleged violations of the Due Process Clause of the Constitution’s Fifth Amendment.

The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to set aside the SEVIS terminations, restore their records, prevent further adverse action absent valid grounds, and prohibit arrest, detention, or removal based on the terminations. Judge Jane M. Beckering presided over the case. On April 23, 2025, the court granted a Temporary Restraining Order requiring DHS to restore the plaintiffs’ SEVIS records retroactively, refrain from terminating or altering these records without lawful cause, and prohibit related enforcement actions. The court found that plaintiffs demonstrated a likelihood of success on their APA claims, irreparable harm absent relief, and that the balance of equities and public interest favored interim relief.

Following further briefing and a hearing on May 6, 2025, the court issued a Preliminary Injunction on May 7, 2025, continuing the protections of the TRO throughout the pendency of the case. The order required DHS to keep the plaintiffs’ SEVIS records active, to annotate the records as restored retroactively, and to ensure that no adverse immigration actions would be taken based on the terminations. The court again found no regulatory or statutory basis for the terminations and rejected DHS’s arguments that general statutory authority permitted the actions. The court waived the security requirement for injunctive relief and denied a motion to hold DHS in contempt after the agency restored the records.

The case did not proceed to trial during the period covered by the record. On July 7, 2025, DHS officials filed an interlocutory appeal of the preliminary injunction order. As of the last docket entry, the case remained pending, with the preliminary injunction in place and no final judgment entered. There were no class claims, no consolidated or related cases identified in the record, and no court-appointed monitor or reported monitor’s findings. The court’s decrees are court-enforced, and compliance disputes were resolved during the preliminary phase. The factual basis of the case centered on the abrupt and unilateral termination of lawful student status records without notice or lawful justification under U.S. immigration law and regulations.
results.46239:
This case was filed on March 17, 2025, in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia by Erie County, New York, a municipal entity, against the Corporation for National and Community Service (AmeriCorps) and its interim agency head, Jennifer Bastress Tahmasebi, in her official capacity. Erie County was represented by private counsel from Gerstein Harrow LLP.

The dispute centered on a federal grant awarded to Erie County under the Retired and Senior Volunteer Program (RSVP), which funds community-based volunteer services for older adults, including Meals on Wheels. Erie County applied for a three-year, approximately $250,000 grant in October 2023, and the grant was approved in January 2024. AmeriCorps regulations, in place since 1999, require grantees to establish advisory councils “of a diverse composition that reflects the demographics of the service area.” Erie County’s grant application described its efforts to foster diversity and inclusion within its volunteer programs and advisory council, in compliance with these rules.

After the grant was awarded, President Trump issued Executive Orders 14151 and 14173 in January 2025, directing federal agencies to end “equity-related” programs and require grant recipients to certify that they do not “promote DEI” (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) activities in violation of federal anti-discrimination laws. In February 2025, AmeriCorps notified Erie County that language in its grant application referencing diversity and DEI required clarification and requested that Erie County either certify it did not promote DEI activities, amend its application, or relinquish the grant. Erie County responded that it adhered to AmeriCorps guidelines, but AmeriCorps insisted on a specific certification. The agency also indicated that failure to respond could result in grant termination, though it suspended enforcement while a preliminary injunction against the executive orders was in effect in a separate case.

Erie County filed suit seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging that AmeriCorps’ new certification requirements were arbitrary and capricious under the Administrative Procedure Act and violated the Spending Clause of the U.S. Constitution by imposing vague and unauthorized conditions on federal funding. Erie County moved for a preliminary injunction to prevent AmeriCorps from enforcing the new certification requirement and to ensure continued disbursement of grant funds.

The case was assigned to Chief Judge James E. Boasberg. The defendants opposed the motion, arguing that Erie County was not at imminent risk of irreparable harm, that any dispute was not ripe, that the court lacked jurisdiction, and that AmeriCorps’ actions were within its discretion under grant statutes and regulations.

On April 14, 2025, before the court ruled on any substantive motions, Erie County voluntarily dismissed the case without prejudice, stating that AmeriCorps had changed its certification requirements since the filing of the suit. No reported opinions, trials, decrees, settlements, or monitors were issued in this matter. There were no related or consolidated cases in this docket, though the parties referenced a preliminary injunction in a separate District of Maryland case challenging the same executive orders.
results.46230:
This case was filed on March 14, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia by twelve individual plaintiffs, all career civil servants formerly employed in the Office of Equity Assurance (OEA) within the Veterans Benefits Administration (VBA), part of the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel, challenged actions taken by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs following the issuance of Executive Order 14151 by President Trump on January 20, 2025, which directed the termination of all federal diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility (DEIA) programs and related offices.

The plaintiffs alleged that, in the wake of this executive order, the VA erroneously designated the OEA as a DEIA office, placed all OEA employees on administrative leave, and subsequently initiated a reduction in force (RIF) resulting in their terminations. The plaintiffs claimed that these actions were taken without proper notice, due process, or opportunities for reassignment, and that the RIF procedures deviated from established agency practice and relevant regulations. They asserted that, unlike other affected offices, the VA denied them access to various employment benefits and professional opportunities, stigmatized them as DEIA employees, and impeded their future federal employment prospects.

The legal claims were brought under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the First Amendment (freedom of speech and association), and the Fifth Amendment (due process and equal protection), seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to bar the VA from designating OEA and its staff as DEIA-related, as well as compensatory damages and attorneys’ fees.

Judge Rudolph Contreras presided over the case. Early in the proceedings, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a temporary restraining order to halt their designation as DEIA employees and restore access to employment resources. The court denied this motion on May 2, 2025, after a hearing, for reasons stated on the record. No reported written opinions were issued on the merits of the claims, and the docket reflects no trial or decision on the merits.

Although the plaintiffs initially identified the case as related to another federal lawsuit (Perkins Coie LLP v. U.S. Department of Justice et al., No. 1:25-cv-00716), the court found the cases were not factually or transactionally related and reassigned this matter randomly. There is no indication of consolidated cases, decrees, settlements, court-appointed monitors, or appeals.

On July 17, 2025, the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case without prejudice. No court-enforced settlement or decree was entered, and no further disputes or monitoring were recorded.

The underlying factual basis for the case centered on the plaintiffs' role in the OEA, which was tasked with identifying and addressing disparities in the delivery of veterans’ benefits. The plaintiffs contended they were not engaged in DEIA work as characterized by the executive order and that the government’s actions—publicly and administratively—damaged their reputations and careers, and violated their legal rights. The court’s denial of emergency relief and the subsequent voluntary dismissal concluded the litigation at the district court level.
results.46242:
This case was filed on March 5, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Utah. The parties bringing the suit are BlueRibbon Coalition, Inc. (a national non-profit focused on public land access), the Sage Riders Motorcycle Club (a Utah-based recreational group), and an individual member, Paul Wells. They are represented by private counsel. The defendants are the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) and the U.S. Department of the Interior, both federal agencies responsible for public land management.

The dispute centers on BLM’s approval of the San Rafael Swell Travel Management Plan (TMP), finalized on December 31, 2024, which closed 665 miles of routes to motorized use within the San Rafael Swell Travel Management Area in Emery County, Utah. The plaintiffs allege that these closures were adopted in violation of several federal statutes, including the John D. Dingell, Jr. Conservation, Management, and Recreation Act (“Dingell Act”), the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA), and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). Specifically, they claim that BLM’s TMP unlawfully created “buffer zones” around new wilderness areas, closed access to historic and recreational sites, and failed to adequately consider public input or provide required environmental review. Plaintiffs also argue that the agency relied on invalid or improperly authorized regulations and failed to comply with required procedures for approving and implementing the travel plan.

The causes of action are founded on the APA (5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706), the Dingell Act (16 U.S.C. § 1132 et seq.), and NEPA (42 U.S.C. § 4332(2)(C)), with the plaintiffs seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to set aside the TMP and enjoin its enforcement. They also request attorneys’ fees and costs. No class action is involved; the plaintiffs act in their organizational and individual capacities.

The case is presided over by Judge David Nuffer. Early proceedings included the plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunctive relief to halt implementation of the TMP, arguing irreparable harm if route closures and physical obliteration of trails proceed before the case is resolved. The Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance (SUWA), a conservation non-profit, moved to intervene as a defendant, citing its longstanding interest in protecting the area’s environmental and cultural resources. The court granted SUWA’s intervention as of right on April 21, 2025, finding that SUWA’s interests might be impaired and were not adequately represented by the federal defendants.

No trial, settlement, consent decree, or monitor has been established as of the most recent docket entries. The case is proceeding on an administrative record, with a briefing schedule ordered for dispositive motions and review under the APA.

The factual basis of the dispute includes a history of contentious travel management planning in the San Rafael Swell, extensive public input, previous litigation and settlement over BLM’s management of OHV routes, and the recent congressional designation of new wilderness and recreation areas. Plaintiffs allege that the TMP’s route closures exceed BLM’s statutory authority, fail to comply with environmental review requirements, and deprive them of recreational access and access to historic property. The federal agencies and intervenor contest these claims, defending the TMP as a lawful exercise of BLM’s land management discretion and consistent with federal law. The litigation is ongoing.
results.46039:
On February 4, 2025, a professional association representing FBI agents, alongside several current FBI personnel (special agents, forensic specialists, and analysts), filed suit against the U.S. Department of Justice and the United States in the District of Columbia. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel and nonprofit legal organizations, brought the case in response to anticipated public disclosure of their identities and roles in federal investigations and prosecutions related to the January 6, 2021 Capitol attack.

The plaintiffs allege that following the inauguration of President Trump in January 2025, the administration issued sweeping pardons for individuals prosecuted for January 6-related offenses. The complaint details a subsequent campaign of public threats and harassment by some pardon recipients and administration allies targeting law enforcement personnel involved in those investigations. The plaintiffs further allege that senior Department of Justice officials initiated efforts to collect and possibly disseminate lists identifying FBI employees who participated in January 6 and other politically sensitive investigations, including requiring agents to submit detailed questionnaires about their roles. Plaintiffs contend that these actions were accompanied by the firing or forced resignation of numerous prosecutors and agents, and the threat of further mass terminations.

The legal claims arise under the Privacy Act (5 U.S.C. § 552a), the Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. § 706), and the U.S. Constitution. Plaintiffs allege violations of the Privacy Act’s restrictions on disclosure of records (§ 552a(b)), requirements for accuracy in dissemination (§ 552a(e)(6)), First Amendment retaliation based on perceived political affiliation, and Fifth Amendment due process and privacy violations. They seek injunctive and declaratory relief to prevent the public release or dissemination of personally identifying information about FBI personnel involved in these investigations, as well as writs of mandamus to compel the government to rescind allegedly unlawful termination orders.

Judge Jia M. Cobb presides over the case. It was consolidated with a related action filed by other individual FBI employees raising nearly identical claims. Plaintiffs promptly moved for a temporary restraining order (“TRO”) to prevent disclosure or further collection of agent information. The government opposed, arguing that the information gathering was an internal process permitted under the Privacy Act, that no names were to be released publicly, and that any claims of imminent harm were speculative. The government stated that only anonymized data had been shared within the Department of Justice, and that no public disclosure was planned.

On February 7, 2025, the court entered a consent order, with the government agreeing not to publicly disseminate the list of FBI personnel (including any versions linking unique identifiers to names) pending a ruling on plaintiffs’ anticipated motion for preliminary injunction. The order allows the government, with two business days’ notice, to terminate this restriction in the future at its discretion. The case remains at the preliminary injunction stage, with further briefing scheduled. No reported opinions, trial, decree, settlement, or appeals have occurred to date.

The factual basis of the case centers on high-level government actions following the 2025 presidential inauguration, including mass pardons, reported targeting of law enforcement personnel for termination, and the threatened public identification of agents involved in politically sensitive investigations, all set against a backdrop of documented threats and harassment against such personnel. Plaintiffs allege these actions present ongoing risks to their safety, reputations, and employment, and violate statutory and constitutional protections.
results.46681:
On February 3, 2025, a private citizen filed suit in the U.S. Court of International Trade challenging the President’s imposition of tariffs on imported goods from Canada, Mexico, and China. The plaintiff acted pro se, without attorney representation, and brought the case against the United States and President Donald J. Trump. The plaintiff alleged that recent executive orders imposing tariffs violated Article I, Sections 7 and 8 of the U.S. Constitution by usurping Congress’s exclusive authority to impose tariffs and raise revenue, thereby breaching the separation of powers. The complaint also challenged several federal statutes and legislative acts, including the Tariff Act of 1930, the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act of 1934, the Trade Expansion Act of 1962, the Trade Act of 1974, and the National Emergencies Act of 1976, under which the President asserted authority to act. The plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief to halt the collection of these tariffs, a ruling that the President cannot constitutionally be delegated tariff-imposing powers, and an order compelling the President to adhere to constitutional duties. The plaintiff did not seek a jury trial.

The United States, represented by the Department of Justice, moved to dismiss the complaint under Rule 12(b)(1), arguing lack of Article III standing and prudential standing. The government contended that the plaintiff, as a consumer rather than an importer, did not allege a particularized or concrete injury traceable to the tariffs or redressable by the court, and that only parties directly affected by the tariffs—such as importers—were properly situated to challenge their validity.

Judge Jennifer Choe-Groves presided over the case. On May 23, 2025, the court granted the government’s motion to dismiss without prejudice, holding that the plaintiff failed to establish Article III standing. The court found the plaintiff’s alleged injury—a general breach of the constitutional contract and speculative economic harm as a consumer—was neither concrete nor particularized, but rather shared broadly with the public. As a result, the court lacked subject matter jurisdiction and did not address the merits of the constitutional claims. No trial was held, no decree or settlement was entered, and there were no reported opinions or appeals at this stage. The court granted the plaintiff leave to file an amended complaint to address the identified deficiencies by June 23, 2025.
results.46758:
On June 20, 2025, a group of individual Latino residents of the Los Angeles area—some U.S. citizens, some lawful residents, and some noncitizens—along with three membership organizations representing workers and immigrants, filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California. The case is a putative class action. The plaintiffs are represented by private counsel, including attorneys from legal services and civil rights organizations. The defendants are senior officials and agencies of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, including Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and Customs and Border Protection (CBP), represented by government counsel.

The case arises from “Operation At Large,” a large-scale federal immigration enforcement operation launched in Los Angeles on June 6, 2025. Plaintiffs alleged that federal agents, organized in “contact teams” or “roving patrols,” were conducting widespread stops and detentions of individuals in public places and at businesses such as carwashes, bus stops, and Home Depots, targeting people based on apparent race or ethnicity, language, location, and type of work. Numerous sworn declarations described stops where agents detained and interrogated individuals, sometimes using force or threats, without reasonable suspicion or probable cause that the persons were unlawfully present in the United States. U.S. citizens and lawful residents were among those stopped.

The plaintiffs brought claims under the U.S. Constitution, specifically alleging violations of the Fourth Amendment’s prohibition on unreasonable seizures. They sought injunctive and declaratory relief to prohibit federal agents from conducting detentive stops for immigration enforcement without individualized, reasonable suspicion that a person is unlawfully present in the United States. They also sought class certification for a class of all individuals at risk of such stops in the Central District of California.

Judge Maame Ewusi-Mensah Frimpong presided over the case. After expedited briefing, on July 11, 2025, the district court granted plaintiffs’ applications for a temporary restraining order (TRO). The order enjoined federal defendants from conducting detentive stops in the Central District unless agents had reasonable suspicion that the person stopped was unlawfully present, and specifically prohibited reliance solely on apparent race or ethnicity, speaking Spanish or English with an accent, presence at certain locations, or type of work as bases for reasonable suspicion. The court found plaintiffs likely to succeed in showing that the challenged stops were part of an officially sanctioned pattern of conduct not supported by reasonable suspicion and that such practices were likely to recur, warranting district-wide injunctive relief.

The federal defendants appealed the TRO to the Ninth Circuit and sought a stay. The Ninth Circuit, in a published order on August 1, 2025 (25-4312), denied the stay in all respects except to suspend the clause “except as permitted by law” in the district court’s order as impermissibly vague. The appellate court affirmed the district court’s findings that plaintiffs and the class had standing, that a pattern of stops without reasonable suspicion was likely to recur, and that the TRO’s substantive terms were consistent with the Fourth Amendment and not impermissibly vague or overbroad, given the scope and nature of the relief sought.

Separately, one named individual plaintiff, Carlos Osorto, sought and obtained habeas corpus relief from immigration detention. Magistrate Judge Sheri Pym granted his ex parte application for release on July 30, 2025. The court found that Osorto’s ongoing detention, combined with inconsistent positions taken by DHS regarding his entitlement to a bond hearing and his serious medical needs, constituted extraordinary circumstances justifying immediate release on a $5,000 bond and electronic monitoring.

The case has involved multiple important filings, including motions for TRO, opposition briefs, reply briefs, motions to intervene by city and county governments, and motions for class certification and preliminary injunctions. No trial has taken place as of August 2025, and proceedings on preliminary injunction and class certification are ongoing. Reported opinions include 2025 WL 1915964 (district court TRO) and the Ninth Circuit’s published order on the stay.

No settlement or consent decree has been entered, and the TRO remains in effect (as modified by the Ninth Circuit). The court’s order is district-wide but limited to the Central District of California. The court has not appointed a monitor. The factual basis for the case centers on federal immigration enforcement practices in Los Angeles in June and July 2025, involving widespread stops and detentions based on broad profiles rather than individualized suspicion.
results.46378:
The case was filed on April 10, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan by four international students—two at the University of Michigan and two at Wayne State University—against the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, the Acting Director of U.S. Customs and Immigration Enforcement, and the Detroit Field Office Director of ICE, all in their official capacities. The students were represented by private counsel, including cooperating attorneys with the American Civil Liberties Union Fund of Michigan.

The students alleged that, beginning around April 4, 2025, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and its agencies terminated their active records in the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS), a federal database used to monitor noncitizen students in the United States. The terminations were reportedly based on either criminal history checks or visa revocations, as reflected in SEVIS termination notices received by the students’ universities. The students stated that they had not been convicted of any crimes; some had only minor prior encounters with law enforcement, such as dismissed arrests or traffic violations. Two students were notified by the Department of State that their visas were “prudentially” revoked, while the other two were not notified of any visa action.

The students claimed they received no advance notice, explanation, or opportunity to respond before the SEVIS terminations, and only learned of the actions through their universities. They asserted that these actions placed them at risk of immediate removal, loss of student status, loss of employment, and disruption of their education and future prospects. The complaint also alleged that these SEVIS terminations were part of a broader, nationwide pattern affecting hundreds of international students at numerous U.S. universities.

The core legal claims were that the government’s actions violated the students’ Fifth Amendment procedural due process rights and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). Specifically, the students argued that SEVIS record termination amounted to termination of F-1 student status, for which federal regulations require cause and due process. They sought emergency relief—including a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction—requiring restoration of their SEVIS records and F-1 status, prohibiting removal or detention based on the terminations, and preventing further adverse actions without proper process.

The government opposed the emergency relief, arguing that SEVIS is an administrative database that does not, by itself, control or conclusively reflect a student’s lawful immigration status. The government stated that the termination of SEVIS records did not equate to termination of F-1 status, that the students were not subject to removal proceedings, and that no immediate harm or irreparable injury was present. The government also noted that the students could seek administrative reinstatement of their status and that judicial review under the APA was not available because no final agency action affecting legal rights had occurred.

On April 17, 2025, Judge Stephen J. Murphy III denied the motion for a temporary restraining order. The court found the factual and legal record insufficient to determine whether the SEVIS terminations were synonymous with loss of F-1 status or had independent legal consequences. The court noted that the government expressly disclaimed any current intent to remove the students or to treat them as out of status, and that the plaintiffs had not shown a strong likelihood of success on the merits or irreparable harm. The judge set a schedule for further briefing and an evidentiary hearing on the preliminary injunction. No final merits ruling or settlement had been entered as of the TRO denial, and no class action was asserted; the plaintiffs proceeded as individuals. No appeals or consolidated cases were referenced at this stage.

The factual basis of the case centers on the DHS’s termination of SEVIS records for several Michigan university students—without individualized notice or hearing—based on alleged criminal history or visa revocation, and the resulting risk of loss of lawful status, employment, and educational opportunity. The case remains pending, with further proceedings scheduled to resolve the plaintiffs’ claims for injunctive and declaratory relief.
results.46385:
This case was filed on April 9, 2025, in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois. The plaintiffs are two law professors and clinical legal educators at Northwestern University’s Pritzker School of Law—one the director of the Community Justice and Civil Rights Clinic and the other a long-serving leader of the Center on Negotiation, Mediation, and Restorative Justice. The defendants are the United States House of Representatives Committee on Education and Workforce, its chair and subcommittee chair, all sued in their official capacities. Northwestern University, its president, and its board chair are named as nominal defendants due to their possession of the records at issue and because they are targets of the committee’s demands.

The plaintiffs are represented by private counsel, including attorneys from People’s Law Office, Loevy & Loevy, and the Center for Constitutional Rights.

The lawsuit arises from a March 27, 2025, letter from the House Committee demanding that Northwestern University produce extensive records related to the operation, funding, and governance of its legal clinics, particularly focusing on the plaintiffs’ clinics and the plaintiffs’ own employment records. The Committee’s stated justification was concern over the university’s provision of legal representation to pro-Palestinian protestors in a civil suit, which the Committee described as supporting “illegal, antisemitic conduct” and “left-wing political activism.”

The plaintiffs allege that the Committee’s demands are not legitimately related to any valid legislative purpose and are instead intended to punish and intimidate institutions and individuals based on perceived political viewpoints and associations. The complaint asserts that such demands violate the First Amendment (freedom of speech, association, academic freedom, and right to petition), the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process and Equal Protection guarantees, and the Sixth Amendment’s right to counsel. The plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief—specifically, an order barring Northwestern from producing the demanded documents and declaring the Committee’s demands unconstitutional.

The factual background details a pattern of targeting by the federal government and Congress under the Trump Administration, including threats to withdraw federal funding from universities and punitive executive orders directed at law firms representing disfavored clients. The complaint outlines the clinics’ roles in providing legal services to marginalized individuals and describes the chilling effect and potential harm to students, clients, donors, and academic programs if Northwestern were to comply with the Committee’s demands.

On April 9, 2025, the plaintiffs filed an emergency motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) to prevent Northwestern from complying with the Committee’s deadline for document production, set for April 10, 2025, at 11:00 a.m. Central Time. Judge Andrea R. Wood, acting as emergency judge, held a hearing on the TRO motion on April 10, 2025. The motion was denied as moot and without prejudice; details as to the mootness were stated on the record but are not specified in the docket entry provided. The case was assigned to Judge Elaine E. Bucklo for further proceedings.

No reported judicial opinions have been issued to date. No trial has been held, and there is no indication of settlement or a court-enforced decree. As of June 24, 2025, the proceedings are stayed by joint motion of the parties, with a joint status report due in September 2025.

The underlying facts supporting the legal claims center on the Committee’s document demand targeting the clinics and their leadership, the context of broader executive and legislative actions aimed at suppressing certain speech and advocacy, and the threatened loss of federal funding. The plaintiffs argue these actions constitute unconstitutional viewpoint discrimination and threaten irreparable harm to academic freedom, legal advocacy, and the rights of clients and donors.

No consolidated or related cases are referenced as being joined for proceedings or directly connected. No special monitor or court-appointed oversight is involved.

The presiding judge for substantive proceedings is Judge Elaine E. Bucklo. The emergency motion was handled by Judge Andrea R. Wood as emergency judge.

In summary, this case presents constitutional challenges by faculty of a university legal clinic to congressional demands for sensitive information, arising in the context of wider federal efforts to control or punish advocacy and association deemed politically disfavored. The matter is currently stayed, with no final court ruling on the merits or injunctive relief as of the latest docket entries.
results.46353:
This case was filed on April 7, 2025, in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California by an individual plaintiff, an international student employed under post-graduate STEM Optional Practical Training (OPT) and residing in the district. The plaintiff is represented by private counsel from Van Der Hout LLP and proceeds under a pseudonym due to concerns about retaliation.

The defendants are the President of the United States, the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Acting Director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), and the Acting Field Office Director of ICE’s San Francisco Office, all sued in their official capacities.

The plaintiff challenges ICE’s termination of their Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) record, which ICE marked as “Otherwise Failing to Maintain Status” on March 28, 2025, citing a minor misdemeanor conviction. The plaintiff alleges that the conviction is not for a crime of violence, did not carry a potential sentence of more than one year, and was previously disclosed to DHS, which had granted immigration benefits thereafter. The complaint asserts that the college did not initiate the SEVIS termination and that the plaintiff remains in compliance with all F-1 visa requirements.

The plaintiff alleges that the federal government, since late March 2025, has engaged in a widespread policy of terminating SEVIS records and revoking visas for hundreds of international students, disproportionately affecting African, Arab, Middle Eastern, Muslim, and Asian students. The complaint further alleges that these actions have led to arrests, detentions, and transfers of affected students to detention facilities far from their communities, without prior notice or process.

The legal claims are brought under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Declaratory Judgment Act, and the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause. The plaintiff alleges that ICE lacked statutory or regulatory authority to terminate the SEVIS record based on the cited grounds, that the termination was arbitrary and capricious under the APA, and that the plaintiff was denied procedural due process. The complaint also alleges a discriminatory pattern in violation of the Accardi doctrine.

The statutory and constitutional bases invoked include 8 U.S.C. §§ 1101(a)(15)(F)(i), 1227(a)(1)(C), 1372 (governing F-1 status and SEVIS), APA provisions (5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706), and the Fifth Amendment. The plaintiff seeks declaratory and injunctive relief—specifically, to set aside the SEVIS termination, restore the SEVIS record and F-1 status, enjoin any enforcement action arising from the termination or minor conviction, and prevent detention, transfer, or removal during litigation.

The case was assigned to Judge Jeffrey S. White. Shortly after filing, the plaintiff moved for a temporary restraining order (TRO) to prevent arrest, detention, or removal, and to preserve their ability to work and maintain status while the case proceeded. The government opposed, arguing that a SEVIS record termination does not itself terminate F-1 status, that no final agency action had occurred, and that the plaintiff had not shown irreparable harm.

On April 17, 2025, Judge White granted the TRO, enjoining defendants from arresting, incarcerating, or transferring the plaintiff, and prohibiting any legal effect from the SEVIS termination or potential visa revocation during the proceedings. The TRO was subsequently extended for an additional 14 days following a hearing on April 25, 2025. At that hearing, the government reported that SEVIS records for the plaintiff and similarly situated individuals were being restored to active status pending the issuance of a new policy governing SEVIS terminations.

The court scheduled a preliminary injunction hearing for May 13, 2025, and set a briefing schedule for further submissions on the merits and scope of relief. The parties engaged in further briefing, and the SEVIS record for the plaintiff was confirmed as reactivated, with a new Form I-20 issued by the school.

Several related cases involving similar claims by other international students were consolidated or related before Judge White. As of the last available orders, the court’s temporary restraining order remains in effect, and the status of the case is ongoing, with preliminary injunction proceedings underway.

There are no reported opinions yet in this case. No settlement, decree, or monitor has been appointed, and no trial or appeal has occurred as of the date of the latest filings. The legal issues at stake concern the authority of ICE to terminate SEVIS records absent underlying status violations, the procedural rights of international students, and the legal consequences of SEVIS terminations for F-1 status and employment authorization.
results.46337:
On April 3, 2025, nineteen states, each represented by their respective attorneys general, filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts seeking declaratory and injunctive relief against the President of the United States, the Attorney General of the United States, the United States Election Assistance Commission (EAC) and its commissioners, and the Secretary of Defense. The states were represented by public (state attorney general) counsel. The case was assigned to Chief Judge Denise J. Casper.

The states challenged Executive Order No. 14248, issued by President Trump on March 25, 2025, which directed sweeping changes to federal election administration. The Executive Order required, among other things, (1) the EAC to amend the federal mail voter registration form to require documentary proof of U.S. citizenship, (2) the Secretary of Defense to require similar documentation for military and overseas voters using the federal post card application, (3) federal and state voter registration agencies to assess citizenship before providing registration forms to public assistance recipients, (4) enforcement against states whose laws allowed counting of mail ballots received after Election Day or permitted voters to cure minor ballot defects after Election Day, and (5) the conditioning of federal election funding on states’ compliance with a new ballot receipt deadline of Election Day.

The states argued that the Executive Order exceeded presidential authority, violated the Elections Clause and Electors Clause of the Constitution by usurping powers reserved to Congress and the states, and conflicted with the National Voter Registration Act (NVRA), the Help America Vote Act (HAVA), and the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act (UOCAVA). They sought a declaratory judgment and preliminary and permanent injunctions prohibiting enforcement of the challenged provisions.

On June 13, 2025, Judge Casper granted the states’ motion for a preliminary injunction. The court found that the states were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims that the Executive Order’s provisions requiring documentary proof of citizenship for voter registration and military/overseas voting, pre-assessment of citizenship by public assistance agencies, federal enforcement against states’ ballot receipt laws, and conditioning of HAVA funding on compliance with an Election Day ballot receipt deadline were all unauthorized by the Constitution or federal statutes and intruded on state sovereignty. The court determined that these provisions would inflict imminent and irreparable harm on the states by imposing costly and disruptive new administrative burdens, threatening the loss of vital federal election funds, and potentially disenfranchising eligible voters.

The injunction specifically barred the EAC and its commissioners, the Secretary of Defense, and the Attorney General (but not the President in his official capacity) from: (1) implementing the documentary proof of citizenship requirement for the federal voter registration form and federal post card application; (2) requiring pre-assessment of citizenship by voter registration agencies before providing registration forms to public assistance recipients; (3) initiating civil or criminal enforcement actions against the thirteen plaintiff states whose laws allow counting of ballots received after Election Day or curing of ballots (California, Nevada, Massachusetts, Arizona, Colorado, Hawaii, Illinois, Maryland, Michigan, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, and Rhode Island); and (4) conditioning federal election funding on adoption of an Election Day ballot receipt deadline for those states. The court also declined to require the states to post a bond.

No trial has been held yet, and the case remains at the preliminary injunction stage. The defendants have since filed a motion to dismiss and appealed the preliminary injunction to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judge Denise J. Casper presides. The case remains ongoing as of August 2025.

The factual basis underlying the case is that the Executive Order, if implemented, would require states to overhaul voter registration systems, impose new documentation and administrative requirements, threaten loss of critical federal election funds, and potentially disenfranchise eligible voters, including those lacking ready access to citizenship documents. The challenged provisions also conflict with longstanding state laws and practices regarding voter registration and ballot processing.
results.46238:
This case was filed on March 17, 2025, in the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey by two individual plaintiffs, both transgender men who serve as active-duty members of the United States Air Force. The plaintiffs challenged a series of executive orders and implementing policies issued by President Donald J. Trump and the Department of Defense in early 2025, which reversed prior policy and banned transgender individuals from serving in the U.S. military. The challenged orders required all service members to serve in their birth sex and prohibited recognition of gender identity for purposes of military service, pronoun usage, and access to facilities. The plaintiffs, both of whom had previously transitioned and served openly under prior policy, alleged that these new orders led to immediate adverse actions, including forced administrative leave and the imminent threat of involuntary separation from service.

The plaintiffs were represented by private counsel as well as attorneys from civil rights organizations including GLBTQ Legal Advocates & Defenders and the National Center for Lesbian Rights. The lawsuit was not a class action, but was brought by the individual service members. The defendants were the United States, the Secretary of Defense, the Acting Secretary of the Air Force, and the Department of the Air Force, all sued in their official capacities.

The plaintiffs asserted multiple causes of action under the U.S. Constitution, specifically alleging violations of the Equal Protection component of the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause. They argued that the new policies discriminated on the basis of sex and transgender status, lacked any rational or sufficient governmental justification, and were motivated by animus. They also asserted claims for procedural due process, estoppel, and injunctive relief.

The case was assigned to Judge Christine P. O’Hearn. On March 18, 2025, the plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order (TRO) to prevent the initiation of administrative separation proceedings against them. The court, after briefing and oral argument, granted a 14-day TRO on March 24, 2025, enjoining the government from initiating separation actions against the plaintiffs based on their transgender status and from enforcing the challenged orders as to them. In her order, Judge O’Hearn found that the plaintiffs demonstrated a likelihood of success on the merits of their constitutional claims and faced immediate, irreparable harm if the policies were enforced.

No trial was held, and there were no reported opinions or appeals in this case. The court’s TRO was limited to the two individual plaintiffs and did not address classwide or nationwide relief. The case referenced a related nationwide preliminary injunction issued by a federal district court in the District of Columbia in the case Talbott v. United States, which enjoined enforcement of the same executive orders and policies on a nationwide basis.

Following the issuance of the TRO and ongoing related litigation in other federal courts, the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed their case without prejudice on May 15, 2025. There were no consent decrees, settlements, or court-appointed monitors. The court did not retain jurisdiction following dismissal, and there are no reported disputes over enforcement.

The underlying facts of the case centered on the plaintiffs’ long and honorable military service, the abrupt change in federal policy banning transgender persons from military service, and the plaintiffs’ removal from duty and threatened discharge solely because of their transgender status. The remedy sought was injunctive and declaratory relief to prevent enforcement of the ban as to the plaintiffs and to protect their right to continue serving on equal terms.
results.46234:
This case was filed on March 15, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York, by a group consisting of a non-citizen graduate student at Cornell University (a citizen of the United Kingdom and The Gambia), his professor (a U.S. citizen), and another U.S. citizen graduate student. The plaintiffs were represented by private counsel and lawyers from the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee and Project TAHA. The case was presided over by Judge Elizabeth C. Coombe.

The plaintiffs challenged the enforcement of two executive orders issued by the President of the United States: Executive Order 14161, "Protecting the United States from Foreign Terrorists and Other National Security and Public Safety Threats," and Executive Order 14188, "Additional Measures to Combat Anti-Semitism." The defendants included the President in his official capacity, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Secretary of DHS, and, in the amended complaint, the Department of State and its Secretary, the Attorney General, and relevant immigration officials.

The case was brought on behalf of both the individual plaintiffs and similarly situated persons but was not styled as a class action. The main plaintiff, a non-citizen Ph.D. student at Cornell, had a long record of advocacy for Palestinian rights and criticism of U.S. and Israeli government policies. The complaint alleged that, following issuance of the executive orders, the federal government began targeting non-citizen students for removal or criminal prosecution based on participation in protests and speech critical of the U.S. or Israeli governments, conflating such criticism with support for terrorism or anti-Semitism.

The legal claims were grounded in the First Amendment (freedom of speech, association, and the right to receive information), the Fifth Amendment (due process and vagueness), the Administrative Procedures Act, the Immigration and Nationality Act, and the Accardi doctrine. The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to block enforcement of the executive orders as applied to protected speech and association, to enjoin the defendants from deporting or detaining the non-citizen based on his advocacy, and to vacate the revocation of his student visa.

The factual basis for the case included a pattern of public statements from the President and administration officials threatening to deport or prosecute students who participated in pro-Palestinian or anti-Israel protests, the active monitoring of universities, and actual enforcement actions, including the revocation of the main plaintiff's visa and attempts by DHS and ICE to locate and detain him. The complaint alleged that these actions chilled protected speech and association for both non-citizens and citizens.

Significant filings included motions for a temporary restraining order (TRO) and preliminary injunction to prevent enforcement actions against the main plaintiff and to protect the speech rights of all plaintiffs. The court denied the TRO on March 27, 2025 (2025 WL 327875), ruling that it lacked subject matter jurisdiction over removal proceedings under 8 U.S.C. § 1252, and that plaintiffs had not established standing or a sufficient showing of imminent irreparable harm. The court found that the claims relating to the commencement of removal proceedings must be addressed through the immigration court process and, if necessary, on appeal after a final order of removal. The court also found the claims of the citizen plaintiffs insufficiently concrete or redressable at this stage.

An amended complaint and habeas petition were filed on March 27, 2025, adding further factual allegations and claims regarding the revocation of the visa and the process for removal. No trial or reported opinions occurred, and the case did not proceed to a final merits ruling. On March 31, 2025, the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the action without prejudice under Rule 41(a)(1)(A)(i), and the court ordered the case closed. There were no decrees, settlements, or court-appointed monitors. No appeals were filed as the case was dismissed at the plaintiffs’ request.

In summary, the case challenged the use of executive orders and related immigration enforcement actions against a non-citizen student and others on First and Fifth Amendment grounds, seeking to protect expressive and associational rights in the context of protests and campus advocacy, but was dismissed without prejudice following denial of interim injunctive relief and before resolution on the merits.
results.46216:
This case was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts on March 12, 2025, by two physicians and Harvard Medical School professors. The plaintiffs challenged the removal of their peer-reviewed medical articles from the federally funded Patient Safety Network (PSNet), an online resource operated by the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ), part of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). The federal defendants included the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM), its Acting Director, HHS and its Secretary, AHRQ, and AHRQ’s Acting Director. The plaintiffs were represented by private counsel from the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and the Media Freedom & Information Access Clinic at Yale Law School.

The case arose after President Trump issued Executive Order 14168, “Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government,” on January 20, 2025. The order directed federal agencies to remove any outward-facing media, including web content, that “promotes or inculcates gender ideology.” OPM implemented this directive through a memorandum mandating that all agencies take down such materials, citing its statutory authority. HHS and AHRQ responded by removing content from PSNet that contained terms such as “LGBTQ,” “transgender,” and related language, identified through targeted word searches.

The plaintiffs’ removed articles discussed diagnostic safety concerning suicide risk and endometriosis, each referencing higher risks or diagnostic considerations for LGBTQ and transgender individuals. The AHRQ notified the authors that their articles would only be restored if they agreed to delete or alter references to these terms, which the plaintiffs refused, asserting scientific integrity and accuracy.

The plaintiffs brought suit under the First Amendment, claiming unconstitutional viewpoint discrimination in a government-created limited public forum, and under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), alleging that the agency actions were arbitrary and capricious and exceeded statutory authority. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including restoration of their censored materials and an order enjoining further censorship.

Judge Leo T. Sorokin presided over the case. The plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction. After full briefing and a hearing, the Court granted the motion in part on May 23, 2025. The Court found that the removal of the articles constituted viewpoint discrimination in violation of the First Amendment and likely arbitrary and capricious action under the APA. Judge Sorokin ordered the defendants to restore, within seven days, the plaintiffs’ unaltered articles and all other content authored by private parties that was removed from PSNet pursuant to implementation of the Executive Order. The injunction did not require the court to supervise future content decisions or enjoin all possible future implementation of the Executive Order.

As of the Court’s ruling, PSNet’s technical support contract had expired, but the Court determined that restoration of the censored materials remained technically feasible and necessary to remedy ongoing constitutional harm. The litigation remains pending, with a motion to dismiss filed by the defendants on June 16, 2025, arguing mootness, lack of standing, and ripeness.

No trial has been held, no settlement or consent decree has been entered, and the preliminary injunction remains in effect pending further proceedings. There is no court-appointed monitor, nor have there been any reported disputes over settlement enforcement or decree compliance. The case is not a class action and involves only the two individual physician plaintiffs. There are no noted consolidated or related cases directly in this court, though reference is made to similar litigation in the District of Columbia.
results.46207:
This case was filed on March 7, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia by a group of incarcerated transgender individuals, represented by the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation, the Transgender Law Center, Morgan Lewis LLP, and the ACLU Foundation of the District of Columbia. The plaintiffs brought the action on behalf of themselves and a class of all people in Bureau of Prisons (BOP) custody diagnosed with gender dysphoria who are or would be eligible for gender-affirming health care but for the ban imposed by Executive Order 14168 and its implementing memoranda. The defendants are the President of the United States, the Attorney General, and senior BOP officials, all sued in their official capacities.

The lawsuit challenges the implementation of Executive Order 14168, signed by President Trump on January 20, 2025, which directed the BOP to prohibit the use of federal funds for any medical procedure, treatment, or drug intended to conform an inmate’s appearance to that of the opposite sex. The BOP issued two memoranda in February 2025 to implement this policy, resulting in the categorical denial of gender-affirming health care and accommodations, including hormone therapy and access to gender-affirming clothing or commissary items, for transgender inmates. Prior to the executive order, BOP policy allowed individualized, medically-indicated gender-affirming care in accordance with accepted medical standards.

The plaintiffs allege that these actions violate the Eighth Amendment’s prohibition on cruel and unusual punishment by denying medically necessary care, the Fifth Amendment’s guarantee of equal protection, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act by discriminating on the basis of disability. They further allege that the BOP’s actions violate the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) as arbitrary, capricious, and contrary to constitutional right. The plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief to set aside the challenged policies and require the BOP to restore access to gender-affirming care.

Judge Royce C. Lamberth presides over the case. The court provisionally certified the class, finding numerosity, commonality, and adequacy of representation under Rule 23, and appointed plaintiffs’ counsel as class counsel. The court granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction and class certification on June 3, 2025, ordering the BOP to make available social accommodations and hormone therapy to all class members as previously provided before the executive order. The ruling was based on the likelihood of plaintiffs’ success on their APA claims, finding that the BOP’s actions lacked reasoned explanation, treated gender dysphoria differently from other medical conditions without justification, and failed to consider the reliance interests of affected inmates. The court did not reach the constitutional claims at this stage.

No trial has occurred, and the case is ongoing. There have been no reported appeals as of the date of the latest order. The court has not issued a final decree or settlement; preliminary injunctive relief remains in effect. The court has not appointed a monitor. The case is related to Doe v. McHenry, another challenge to federal prison policies affecting transgender inmates. The factual basis centers on the abrupt termination of gender-affirming care for transgender people in BOP custody, the resulting harms to class members’ health and well-being, and the administrative process leading up to and following the executive order.
results.46104:
This case was filed on February 11, 2025, in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia by American Oversight, a nonpartisan, non-profit organization dedicated to government transparency. The defendants are federal government entities: the U.S. Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), U.S. DOGE Service (USDS), U.S. DOGE Service Temporary Organization, U.S. Digital Service, and the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). American Oversight is represented by private counsel.

American Oversight brought this action under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the Declaratory Judgment Act, 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–2202. The plaintiff seeks declaratory and injunctive relief to compel the defendants to process and produce records in response to eight FOIA requests—including two requests for expedited processing—concerning the activities, communications, and leadership of DOGE and its key personnel, particularly Elon Musk.

The underlying facts center on the creation and rapid expansion of DOGE, which was announced by President Trump in November 2024, with Elon Musk publicly identified as its head. DOGE was established through executive orders that restructured the U.S. Digital Service, created the USDS Temporary Organization, and embedded DOGE teams across at least fifteen federal agencies. Public reporting and the complaint allege DOGE staff, under Musk’s direction, exercised substantial authority: issuing directives to federal agencies, gaining access to sensitive government systems, freezing funds and contracts, and overseeing mass personnel actions. The White House and the government have issued conflicting statements about DOGE’s structure, Musk’s role, and to whom DOGE staff are accountable.

On January 30 and February 3, 2025, American Oversight submitted multiple FOIA requests to DOGE and OMB, seeking communications, records of key personnel, and information related to the firing of inspectors general from numerous agencies. The requests cited an urgent public interest due to widespread media attention and concerns over government integrity. The defendants acknowledged receipt of these requests but failed to issue determinations within the statutory deadlines or grant expedited processing. American Oversight alleges that DOGE failed to preserve potentially responsive records, including communications on ephemeral messaging platforms.

The case is before Judge Beryl A. Howell. There are no consolidated cases, but the complaint references other related litigation involving DOGE’s status and activities, including American Federation of Labor & Congress of Industrial Organizations v.
