Department of Labor and CREW v. U.S. DOGE Service, in which courts have examined similar agency status questions.

Key filings include American Oversight’s motion for a preservation order, which the court granted, requiring the defendants to preserve all potentially responsive records. The defendants filed an answer denying or deflecting on most factual allegations regarding their agency status and the extent of their authority. A central dispute in the case is whether DOGE and its components are “agencies” subject to FOIA, or whether they fall within the President’s immediate personal staff and are therefore exempt. The court has not yet ruled on the merits of this question.

American Oversight filed a motion for limited discovery to obtain evidence regarding DOGE’s actual authority, structure, and operations, arguing that factual development is necessary to resolve whether DOGE wields independent authority and is thus subject to FOIA. The government opposes discovery, asserting the issue can be resolved as a matter of law.

The relief sought includes orders requiring the defendants to process all FOIA requests (including expedited requests), conduct adequate searches, and produce all non-exempt responsive records, along with Vaughn indexes for any claims of exemption. American Oversight also seeks attorneys’ fees and costs.

As of the latest docket entries, the case remains in pre-discovery motion practice, with the court considering whether to permit limited discovery on the threshold question of DOGE’s agency status. No reported opinions or substantive rulings on the merits have yet been issued, and no decree, settlement, or monitoring has occurred. The plaintiff’s claims rest on both statutory interpretation and a detailed factual record regarding DOGE’s actual conduct and role within the executive branch.
results.46602:
This case arises from actions taken by the federal government in 2025 to terminate longstanding federal grant funding for state and jurisdictional humanities councils across the United States. On May 15, 2025, the Oregon Council for the Humanities (a nonprofit distributing NEH funds in Oregon) and the Federation of State Humanities Councils (a national nonprofit whose members are nearly all such state councils) filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon. Both are represented by private counsel.

The lawsuit targets the United States DOGE Service (a newly created executive office component), its Acting Administrator, the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH), the NEH’s advisory council, and NEH’s Acting Chairman. The plaintiffs challenge federal actions that began in March and April 2025, when DOGE and NEH leadership, acting on directives from the Trump Administration and pursuant to new executive orders, abruptly terminated nearly all NEH grants to state and jurisdictional humanities councils. This included the elimination of nearly all staff in NEH’s Office of Federal/State Partnership, mass termination of grants (including those already approved and in progress), and suspension or delay of reimbursements to the councils. The plaintiffs allege these actions were taken without notice, individualized review, or opportunity for appeal, and that they disregarded statutory funding formulas and procedures.

The plaintiffs brought claims under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the U.S. Constitution’s Separation of Powers, and related statutes. They alleged that the defendants’ actions violated the statutory framework governing NEH (20 U.S.C. § 956), which requires NEH to fund state humanities councils using mandatory formulas and to provide notice and hearing before terminating grants. Plaintiffs also alleged violations of the Appropriations Clause, the Impoundment Control Act (ICA), and the Take Care Clause, arguing that the executive branch cannot unilaterally refuse to spend funds appropriated by Congress or bypass the statutory process for impounding or rescinding funds.

The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, asking the court to set aside the grant terminations, compel NEH to allocate and disburse congressionally appropriated funds according to statutory formulas, and prohibit the reallocation of those funds for other purposes. They also requested a preliminary injunction to prevent further harm during litigation.

After plaintiffs filed suit, NEH attempted a partial rescission, restoring some grant funding but at half the previous level, and maintained the termination of numerous other grants. Plaintiffs argued this did not cure the unlawfulness or the harm.

Judge Michael H. Simon presided over the case. On August 6, 2025, the court granted in part the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction and stay under the APA. The court found that plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of several claims. It held that NEH had violated both the Separation of Powers and federal law by refusing to spend appropriated funds as directed by Congress, failing to follow the statutory formula and procedures for funding state humanities councils, and terminating grants without the required findings, notice, or opportunity for hearing. The court concluded that the ICA did not provide a private right of action but could serve as a standard for “contrary to law” claims under the APA. The court also found that the abrupt cessation of funding caused irreparable harm to the plaintiffs and to public access to humanities programming across the country.

The court issued an injunction and stay prohibiting NEH and related defendants from implementing the April 2, 2025 terminations of grants to the plaintiffs (including Federation member councils), from further terminating or suspending approved grants except as permitted by statute, and from reallocating or disbursing the obligated funds to any party other than the plaintiffs. The court directed this relief to be prohibitory, not mandatory, and declined to require a bond. The court found venue proper in Oregon and confirmed the associational standing of the Federation to seek relief for its members.

As of the court’s order, no trial had occurred, no settlement had been reached, and no appeals had been decided. The court’s opinion addresses only preliminary relief pending further proceedings. The case remains ongoing, with the preliminary injunction and stay in place.
results.46478:
This case arises from a challenge by two private, family-owned American companies that develop and sell educational products for children, Learning Resources, Inc. and hand2mind, Inc., to a series of executive orders issued by the President of the United States. The case was filed on April 22, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia and is presided over by Judge Rudolph Contreras. Plaintiffs are represented by private counsel.

The plaintiffs import most of their products from China and other countries. Beginning in early 2025, the President issued a series of executive orders invoking the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (“IEEPA”), 50 U.S.C. § 1701 et seq., to impose broad tariffs on imported goods. These included: an initial 10% tariff on all Chinese imports (later raised to 20%), a 10% "universal tariff" on nearly all other imports, and additional "reciprocal" tariffs on imports from specific countries, some as high as 125%. The President declared national emergencies relating to illicit fentanyl from China and to large, persistent U.S. trade deficits, and asserted that these circumstances authorized the imposition of the tariffs under IEEPA. The Department of Homeland Security and other agencies implemented the tariffs by making changes to the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States.

Plaintiffs allege that these tariffs have caused them immediate and irreparable harm, including dramatic increases in costs, lost sales, customer cancellations, and the threat of business failure. They argue that IEEPA does not authorize the President to impose tariffs, and that the challenged executive orders exceed statutory authority and violate the Constitution, including the nondelegation doctrine. Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent the collection of tariffs imposed under these orders.

Defendants, including multiple federal officials and agencies responsible for implementing the tariffs, moved to transfer the case to the U.S. Court of International Trade (CIT), asserting that the CIT has exclusive jurisdiction over tariff-related cases. Plaintiffs opposed transfer, maintaining that IEEPA is not a law “providing for” tariffs as required for CIT jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1581(i).

On May 29, 2025, Judge Contreras denied the government’s motion to transfer and granted plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction. The Court held that it had jurisdiction, finding that IEEPA is not a law “providing for” tariffs because it does not mention tariffs, duties, or similar terms, and because the statutory term “regulate importation” does not encompass the power to impose tariffs. The Court found plaintiffs likely to succeed on the merits, concluding that the President lacks statutory authority under IEEPA to impose tariffs, and that the agency actions implementing the tariffs are therefore ultra vires and in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act. The Court did not reach the nondelegation or alternative statutory arguments.

The Court found that plaintiffs had demonstrated irreparable harm, including the threat to their businesses’ survival and unrecoverable losses, and that the balance of equities and public interest favored a preliminary injunction limited to plaintiffs. The order enjoined collection of tariffs from the plaintiffs under the challenged executive orders, but stayed its effect for 14 days to allow for appeal.

On June 2, 2025, the government moved to stay the injunction pending appeal, citing national security and foreign policy harms and ongoing international negotiations. The Court granted the stay on June 3, 2025, noting that a related permanent injunction issued by the CIT had itself been stayed by the Federal Circuit.

No trial has occurred; no reported opinions beyond the District Court’s May 29, 2025 memorandum opinion and order have issued. The matter is currently stayed pending appeal to the D.C. Circuit.

No settlements, court-appointed monitors, or consent decrees are present in the record. The factual basis of the case is the impact of the President’s IEEPA-based tariffs on the plaintiffs’ import-dependent businesses and the broader assertion of presidential tariff authority absent clear congressional authorization. No disputes over settlement enforcement or monitors’ reports appear in the record. This is not a class action. There are no consolidated or related cases in this court, but similar cases have been filed in other federal courts and the CIT.
results.46390:
This case arises from a challenge by Venezuelan civil immigration detainees in Colorado to the federal government’s invocation of the Alien Enemies Act (“AEA”), 50 U.S.C. § 21 et seq. On March 14, 2025, the President issued a Proclamation invoking the AEA to authorize the summary removal of Venezuelan noncitizens alleged to be members of the criminal gang Tren de Aragua (“TdA”). The Proclamation permitted removals without the procedures guaranteed by federal immigration law and without individualized process to contest the government’s designation.

The plaintiffs—Venezuelan men detained at the Denver Contract Detention Facility—filed this action on April 12, 2025, as a putative class action on behalf of all noncitizens in custody in the District of Colorado who were, are, or will be subject to the Proclamation. They were represented by the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) Foundation, the ACLU of Colorado, and the Rocky Mountain Immigrant Advocacy Network. The named plaintiffs alleged that they were at imminent risk of summary removal to El Salvador under the Proclamation, based on accusations of TdA membership that they denied.

The plaintiffs asserted that the government’s actions violated the AEA itself, the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Convention Against Torture, and the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause. They argued that the AEA authorizes such removals only in time of declared war or military invasion by a foreign nation or government, and that neither the Proclamation nor the facts established that predicate. They also challenged the sufficiency of government notice and process, citing evidence that the government’s notices were in English only, provided as little as twelve hours’ advance warning, and failed to inform detainees of how to contest their designation.

On April 14, 2025, Judge Charlotte N. Sweeney issued an emergency order under the All Writs Act barring the removal of the named plaintiffs and the putative class from Colorado. After briefing and a hearing, the court granted a temporary restraining order (TRO) on April 22, 2025, provisionally certifying the class and requiring the government to provide at least 21 days’ notice, in a language understood by the detainee, before any removal under the Proclamation. The court found that plaintiffs had standing and jurisdiction was proper under habeas corpus statutes. Judge Sweeney held that plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits, finding the Proclamation’s invocation of the AEA was not supported by a military invasion or action by a foreign government, and that the government’s notice procedures were constitutionally deficient.

The government sought a stay of the TRO both in the district court and the Tenth Circuit. The district court denied a stay, and the Tenth Circuit also denied the motion on April 29, 2025, holding that the government had not shown a likelihood of irreparable harm because no imminent removals were scheduled.

On May 6, 2025, Judge Sweeney granted a preliminary injunction, enjoining the government from detaining, transferring, or removing the named plaintiffs and class members under the AEA and Proclamation from the District of Colorado. The court found that the Proclamation exceeded the statutory authority of the AEA, which is limited to times of declared war or military invasion by a foreign nation or government, and that the Proclamation’s reliance on alleged gang activity fell outside the statute’s scope. The court also certified the class under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(2), finding the numerosity, commonality, typicality, and adequacy requirements satisfied.

Throughout, the court emphasized that its orders did not bar the government from prosecuting or removing detainees under ordinary immigration laws, but only from doing so under the AEA Proclamation. On July 7, 2025, the government filed a notice of appeal from the preliminary injunction and class certification orders. As of the notice of appeal, the preliminary injunction remains in effect, and no trial has been held. There is no evidence in the record of a court-appointed monitor or post-settlement enforcement disputes. The court’s orders have not been superseded by any higher court, and the case remains pending on appeal.
results.46499:
On April 11, 2025, a group of individual international students lawfully present in the United States under F-1 student status initiated suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. The plaintiffs are Chinese national students and recent graduates pursuing undergraduate or advanced degrees at U.S. universities, including the University of California, Berkeley; Carnegie Mellon University; University of Cincinnati; University of Texas at Dallas; New York University; and the University of Southern California. They are represented by private counsel at DeHeng Law Offices PC, with the Chinese American Legal Defense Alliance joining as additional counsel in later filings. The defendants are the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Acting Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), and, in the amended complaint, the Secretary of State. All are sued in their official capacities.

The case arises from an unprecedented enforcement action in early April 2025, when DHS, through ICE and in coordination with the Department of State, conducted a nationwide sweep that resulted in the abrupt termination of the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) records of hundreds, and possibly thousands, of international students holding F-1 visas. Termination of SEVIS records renders students immediately out of status, subject to loss of work authorization, forced suspension of studies, loss of housing, and potential accrual of unlawful presence, with severe consequences for reentry to the United States. Most affected students, including the plaintiffs, received no prior notice or individualized explanation, and were not charged with or convicted of any crime. Some had only minor or dismissed legal encounters, while others had no adverse record. Additionally, the Department of State, acting in concert with ICE, revoked the F-1 visas of many affected students.

The plaintiffs allege that these terminations and visa revocations were carried out without notice, explanation, or due process, and were based on an arbitrary policy of targeting students who appeared in a database search (the National Crime Information Center), irrespective of the underlying reason. Plaintiffs challenged these actions under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) as arbitrary and capricious and contrary to law, and on constitutional grounds for violating the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses. They specifically assert that the terminations violated regulatory limits on agency-initiated termination of nonimmigrant status (8 C.F.R. § 214.1(d)), and that the government’s own policy guidance prohibits SEVIS termination solely on the basis of visa revocation. Plaintiffs also challenge the statutory authority for the mass visa revocations, arguing that 8 U.S.C. § 1201(i) does not permit such wholesale action or its use against individuals already present in the United States.

The plaintiffs sought a nationwide declaratory judgment and both preliminary and permanent injunctive relief, requesting restoration of their SEVIS status, reinstatement of affected F-1 visas, and an order barring future terminations or revocations without lawful process.

The case was initially assigned to Judge Susan Illston but later reassigned to Judge Jeffrey S. White and consolidated with other related cases involving similar claims. Early in the proceedings, the plaintiffs moved for a nationwide TRO. On April 18, 2025, Judge Illston granted an ex parte TRO as to the named plaintiffs, enjoining DHS and ICE from taking adverse enforcement action, including arrest or removal, based on the SEVIS termination, pending further hearing. As more cases were filed, the court coordinated the matters for joint consideration.

On May 22, 2025, Judge White granted preliminary injunctive relief to all named plaintiffs and, on a nationwide basis, to similarly situated F-1 students whose SEVIS records had been terminated under the April 2025 enforcement initiative. The court found that SEVIS record termination effectively terminates F-1 status, resulting in loss of lawful presence and severe consequences, and that the government’s actions were likely arbitrary and capricious and not authorized by regulation. The injunction barred the defendants from arresting, incarcerating, or transferring any plaintiff or similarly situated individual nationwide, from imposing any legal effect due to the SEVIS terminations, and from re-terminating SEVIS records except as permitted by regulation. The order also barred the government from reversing the reinstatement of SEVIS records for these individuals without court approval.

The government subsequently appealed the injunction to the Ninth Circuit and moved for a stay pending appeal, arguing that the nationwide scope of relief exceeded the court’s authority, particularly in light of the Supreme Court’s decision in Trump v. CASA, Inc., and that no irreparable harm had been shown following the retroactive restoration of SEVIS records.

Meanwhile, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on July 29, 2025, adding further factual allegations and additional plaintiffs whose visas remained revoked. They sought an amended preliminary injunction to address the continued harms resulting from the Department of State’s mass revocation of visas, which had not been reversed alongside the restoration of SEVIS records. The amended complaint and motion emphasized the lack of statutory or regulatory authority for the mass visa revocations, the ongoing inability of affected students to travel or return home, and the chilling effect on their education and professional opportunities.

No trial has occurred as of the latest filings. The court’s preliminary injunction remains in effect, with the government’s motion for stay and the plaintiffs’ motion for further injunctive relief pending. The court scheduled a further case management conference for September 26, 2025. No class has been certified, but the court’s preliminary injunction currently provides nationwide relief to all similarly situated F-1 students whose SEVIS records were terminated under the challenged policy. 

The factual basis of the case centers on the abrupt, process-free termination of lawful student status and visas for numerous international students, without individualized review, resulting in immediate and severe educational and immigration consequences, and raising systemic questions about the scope of agency authority and the procedural rights of noncitizens lawfully present in the United States.
results.46319:
On March 31, 2025, the National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU), a labor union representing federal employees in thirty-seven agencies, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. The suit was brought against the President of the United States and the heads of various federal agencies and departments, all in their official capacities. The litigation followed the issuance, on March 27, 2025, of Executive Order No. 14,251, which, by presidential determination under 5 U.S.C. § 7103(b)(1), excluded over thirty federal agencies or subdivisions—including twelve where NTEU represents employees—from coverage under the Federal Service Labor-Management Relations Statute (FSLMRS). This action stripped the collective bargaining rights of approximately two-thirds of the federal workforce, including about 104,000 NTEU-represented employees.

The agencies affected were directed by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to cease honoring collective bargaining agreements and to discontinue payroll deductions for union dues, actions which immediately impaired NTEU’s ability to represent its members and caused substantial loss of revenue. The government’s own public statements, including a White House Fact Sheet and OPM Guidance, indicated that the Executive Order was motivated not by particularized national security concerns but by a desire to make federal employees easier to fire and to retaliate against unions perceived as obstructing the administration’s agenda. The Fact Sheet described certain unions, including NTEU, as “hostile” and acknowledged targeting unions that had opposed the President’s policies.

NTEU alleged that the Executive Order exceeded the President’s limited authority under 5 U.S.C. § 7103(b)(1), which allows agency or subdivision exclusions only if the entity’s primary function is intelligence, counterintelligence, investigative, or national security work, and only if the statute cannot be applied consistent with national security. NTEU asserted that none of the agencies or subdivisions excluded by the order plausibly met these criteria, pointing to the agencies’ long histories of collective bargaining without adverse national security impact. NTEU further alleged that the Executive Order was unlawful and ultra vires as it conflicted with both the FSLMRS and Congress’s explicit intent to protect collective bargaining in the federal sector, and that it was also unconstitutional First Amendment retaliation for NTEU’s protected litigation and advocacy against administration policies.

NTEU sought declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent implementation of the Executive Order as to the agencies where it represents employees, as well as a declaration that the OPM Guidance was unlawful. NTEU was represented by private counsel.

The case was assigned to Judge Paul L. Friedman. On April 4, 2025, NTEU moved for a preliminary injunction. On April 25, after briefing and oral argument, the court granted a preliminary injunction enjoining implementation of the Executive Order and OPM Guidance as to the affected NTEU-represented agencies, finding that NTEU was likely to succeed on the merits of its ultra vires claims, had shown irreparable harm, and that the balance of equities and public interest favored relief. The court determined that the President’s stated justifications for the order were pretextual, that the agencies did not have a primary national security function, and that the order was motivated by improper policy and retaliatory considerations.

The government appealed and obtained a stay of the injunction from the D.C. Circuit on May 16, 2025, pending appeal. The appellate panel held that NTEU had not shown irreparable harm sufficient for preliminary relief, but did not address the merits of NTEU’s statutory or constitutional claims.

Following the stay, the parties proceeded to cross-motions for summary judgment. NTEU reiterated its legal and factual arguments that the Executive Order’s exclusions were both individually and collectively ultra vires and retaliatory. The government, represented by the Department of Justice, opposed on jurisdictional grounds, arguing that such claims must be channeled through the FLRA’s administrative process (which NTEU argued was unavailable, since the Executive Order itself removed the agencies from FSLMRS coverage). The government also argued there was no cause of action or waiver of sovereign immunity, and that, on the merits, the President’s determinations under § 7103(b)(1) were non-reviewable, discretionary, and lawful.

No trial has occurred. The case is pending on cross-motions for summary judgment, with briefing completed as of July 17, 2025. The court has not yet issued a final ruling on the merits. There are no consolidated or related cases in the district court, but a parallel case involving similar issues is pending in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit.

**Judge:** Paul L. Friedman  
**Filing Date:** March 31, 2025  
**Type of Counsel:** Private  
**Cause of Action:** Ultra vires claims under 5 U.S.C. § 7103(b)(1); First Amendment retaliation  
**Statutory/Constitutional Basis:** FSLMRS; First Amendment  
**Remedy Sought:** Declaratory and injunctive relief  
**Appeal:** Preliminary injunction stayed by D.C. Circuit (May 16, 2025), appeal pending  
**Factual Basis:** Executive Order excluding agencies from collective bargaining based on purported national security grounds, with evidence showing policy and retaliatory motivations and lack of statutory basis for exclusions.  
**Significant Terms of Relief Sought:** Restore NTEU’s collective bargaining rights, enjoin agency implementation of the Executive Order, and declare the order unlawful as applied to NTEU-represented agencies.  
**Monitoring/Special Master/Settlement:** None.  
**No trial or decree has been entered.**
results.46285:
This case was filed on March 24, 2025, in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia by three nonprofit immigrant rights membership organizations: the Coalition for Humane Immigrant Rights (CHIRLA), UndocuBlack Network, and CASA, Inc. The plaintiffs are represented by private counsel from Justice Action Center and the in-house legal teams of CASA and CHIRLA.

The plaintiffs challenge a series of policies and directives issued by the Trump administration after January 20, 2025, which expanded the application of "expedited removal" procedures to noncitizens who had previously been paroled into the United States through humanitarian parole programs. The key government defendants are the Secretary of Homeland Security (Kristi Noem), the Acting Directors of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Customs and Border Protection (CBP), and U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), and the President of the United States (Donald J. Trump), all sued in their official capacities.

Expedited removal is a statutory procedure under 8 U.S.C. § 1225(b)(1) that allows for rapid deportation of certain noncitizens with minimal process, historically used primarily for individuals encountered at the border or shortly after entry without valid documents or with fraud/misrepresentation. Historically, individuals paroled into the U.S. at ports of entry for humanitarian reasons were not subject to expedited removal once inside the country.

The complaint alleges that, beginning in January 2025, the administration took three principal actions: (1) the January 23, 2025 Huffman Memorandum directed DHS personnel to consider applying expedited removal to any eligible noncitizen, including those previously granted parole, and to terminate removal proceedings or parole status as needed; (2) a February 18, 2025 ICE Directive instructed field personnel to apply expedited removal to “paroled arriving aliens” not seeking asylum, stating there was “no time limit” for such action; and (3) the March 25, 2025 Federal Register Notice formally terminated parole programs for nationals of Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua, and Venezuela (CHNV process), and ended all grants of parole under those programs, with the explicit aim of making these populations eligible for expedited removal.

Plaintiffs assert that these actions unlawfully expose their members—who include many individuals paroled into the country through the now-terminated CHNV and CBP One parole processes—to summary deportation without the due process protections of standard removal proceedings before an immigration judge. They argue that both the statute (8 U.S.C. § 1225(b)(1)) and the agency’s own regulations do not permit expedited removal of individuals who have been lawfully paroled into the United States at a port of entry, regardless of whether their parole has expired or been terminated, and that the recent directives and policy changes are arbitrary, capricious, and contrary to law under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and violate the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.

Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief to bar the government from subjecting individuals who have previously been granted parole at a port of entry to expedited removal, as well as vacatur of the relevant policy directives and termination notices. They also request an order requiring the government to facilitate the return of any of their members wrongfully removed under these policies, and attorneys’ fees.

Judge Jia M. Cobb is presiding over the case. On August 1, 2025, the Court granted Plaintiffs’ motion for a stay of agency action under 5 U.S.C. § 705. The Court held that the challenged agency actions—namely, the January 23 Huffman Memorandum, the February 18 ICE Directive, and the March 25 CHNV Termination Notice—likely exceeded DHS’s statutory authority and were arbitrary and capricious. The Court found that neither the “Arriving Aliens” nor the “Designation” provisions of the expedited removal statute authorized applying expedited removal to individuals who had ever been paroled into the United States at a port of entry, even if their parole had expired or was terminated. The Court also found the agency’s legal justifications internally inconsistent and insufficiently explained, and determined that Plaintiffs’ members faced imminent irreparable harm, such as denial of meaningful process for immigration relief, risk of wrongful removal, and family separation.

The Court stayed the challenged agency actions as to all noncitizens paroled into the United States at a port of entry, not just members of the plaintiff organizations, pending final resolution of the case. The stay does not reinstate the CHNV parole programs themselves but blocks the use of expedited removal against the affected parolee populations under the challenged directives.

Other related litigation challenging the broader expansion of expedited removal (e.g., Make the Road New York v. Huffman, D.D.C. 25-cv-00190) and the termination of parole programs (e.g., Doe v. Noem, D. Mass. 1:25-cv-10495) is pending, but this case is focused on the intersection of those issues as they affect individuals who were previously granted parole at a port of entry.

As of this summary, the government has appealed the stay order to the D.C. Circuit. No trial has been held, and no final merits ruling has been issued. No court-appointed monitor or special master has been assigned, and there are no consolidated cases. The case remains ongoing and under active judicial management.
results.46179:
On February 24, 2025, two Senate-confirmed members of the United States Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB), both affiliated with the Democratic Party, filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. The PCLOB is an independent, multi-member expert agency created by Congress to oversee executive branch counterterrorism policies and ensure the protection of privacy and civil liberties. The plaintiffs challenged their removal from the Board by the President, which they alleged was done without cause and in violation of statutory protections for Board members’ tenure.

The core factual basis of the case was that, in January 2025, shortly after the President took office, the White House requested the resignation of all three Democratic members of the PCLOB. When the plaintiffs did not resign, they were notified by email that their positions were terminated. No cause was provided for their removal. The President left the Board’s sole Republican member in place, which deprived the Board of a quorum necessary to conduct its statutory functions.

The plaintiffs argued that the PCLOB’s organic statute, as amended by Congress in 2007, prohibits removal of Board members without good cause. They relied on statutory text and structure—specifically, the removal of prior language stating that members served at the pleasure of the President, the establishment of fixed six-year terms, the requirement for nonpartisanship and expertise in the Board’s composition, and the Board’s independent oversight and advisory functions for both Congress and the executive branch. The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including reinstatement to their positions, as well as a writ of mandamus if necessary.

The defendants, including the United States, the remaining Board member, the PCLOB Executive Director, the Deputy Director of Presidential Personnel, and the President (all sued in their official capacities), argued that there was no explicit statutory restriction on removal and that, absent such explicit language, the President retained at-will removal authority. They further contended that, even if removal protections existed, reinstatement was not an appropriate remedy.

Judge Reggie B. Walton presided over the case. The parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment, and the matter was briefed and argued on an expedited schedule. On May 21, 2025, the court granted summary judgment for the plaintiffs. Judge Walton held that, while the PCLOB’s statute contained no express removal provision, its structure and function clearly indicated Congress’s intent to restrict presidential removal of Board members absent good cause. The court found the President’s removals unlawful and declared them null and void. The court ordered that both plaintiffs be reinstated as Board members for the remainder of their terms and enjoined the relevant federal officials and their subordinates from treating the plaintiffs as removed or otherwise interfering with their service.

The court’s order provided specific declaratory and injunctive relief, but did not award monetary damages, as the plaintiffs had withdrawn that request and the compensation structure for Board members rendered backpay unavailable. The judgment closed the district court case.

The defendants appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit and sought a stay of the district court’s judgment. Judge Walton denied a stay, but on July 1, 2025, the D.C. Circuit granted a stay pending appeal. The appellate court concluded that the government had satisfied the requirements for a stay, emphasizing that the PCLOB statute did not expressly restrict the President’s removal power, and that the Board’s functions did not support an implied removal restriction under Supreme Court precedent, as PCLOB is not an adjudicatory body. The appellate court further found that allowing the removed members to continue serving would interfere with the President’s constitutional authority and cause irreparable harm to the executive branch, and thus stayed the district court’s order pending further proceedings.

No reported opinions or consolidated or related cases are referenced outside the immediate proceedings and cited authorities. There is no court-appointed monitor and no settlement or consent decree. The plaintiffs were represented by private counsel. The case remains pending on appeal and the district court’s judgment is stayed.
results.46106:
This case was filed on February 11, 2025, in the Southern District of New York by unions representing federal employees (the American Federation of Government Employees, AFL-CIO and the Association of Administrative Law Judges, International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers Judicial Council 1, AFL-CIO), along with several individual current and former federal employees. The defendants are the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM) and its Acting Director Charles Ezell, as well as entities and officials associated with the U.S. DOGE Service—an entity established by executive order on January 20, 2025 (in connection with President Trump’s inauguration), including the U.S. DOGE Service, its Temporary Organization, its Acting Administrator, and Elon Musk (who leads the DOGE Temporary Service).

The plaintiffs are represented by private counsel, including attorneys from Lex Lumina LLP, the Electronic Frontier Foundation, the State Democracy Defenders Fund, and The Chandra Law Firm.

The case arises from President Trump’s creation of the “Department of Government Efficiency” (DOGE) via executive order, reconstituting the U.S. Digital Service as the U.S. DOGE Service and establishing a DOGE Service Temporary Organization within the Executive Office of the President. The executive order directed agencies—including OPM—to ensure DOGE had prompt access to all unclassified agency records, software, and IT systems, subject only to consistency with the law.

Plaintiffs allege that, beginning on January 20, 2025, OPM granted broad, ongoing, and “administrative” access to its highly sensitive personnel systems and records to individuals affiliated with DOGE, including Elon Musk and several young technologists—some of whom had recently worked for Musk’s private companies and, in at least one case, had a history of alleged cybersecurity misconduct. The complaint asserts that these DOGE agents were given access without normal security vetting, proper background checks, or required cybersecurity/privacy training, and that their access included the ability to read, modify, and export personal data for tens of millions of current and former federal employees, job applicants, and their family members. The records at issue included social security numbers, demographic and health data, employment and financial information, and data related to national security positions.

Plaintiffs claim these disclosures and practices violated the Privacy Act of 1974 (5 U.S.C. § 552a), which strictly regulates the disclosure and safeguarding of records in federal systems of records, limiting access to those with a legitimate need in the performance of their duties, and requiring robust administrative, technical, and physical safeguards. They also assert that OPM’s actions were arbitrary and capricious under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and that the DOGE Defendants acted ultra vires (beyond legal authority), since DOGE had no statutory power to direct or control OPM systems or access personnel records.

Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief halting further disclosure, requiring the return or destruction of unlawfully obtained records, and mandating future compliance with the Privacy Act and related federal security standards. They do not seek monetary damages.

The case is presided over by Judge Denise L. Cote. After an initial motion for a temporary restraining order, the plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction. Defendants moved to dismiss, arguing lack of standing, failure to state a claim, and that the Privacy Act and APA did not provide a basis for the relief sought.

On April 3, 2025, Judge Cote denied the motion to dismiss as to the core APA and ultra vires claims, holding that the plaintiffs had plausibly alleged ongoing violations of the Privacy Act and APA, and that they had standing based on concrete privacy and security harms analogous to the tort of intrusion upon seclusion. The judge found that granting broad access to sensitive personal data without proper safeguards or need was, in itself, an actionable injury, even if there was no evidence of public disclosure.

After further proceedings—including review of the administrative record and a hearing with cross-examination of witnesses—Judge Cote on June 9, 2025, granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction. The court found that OPM had in fact granted DOGE agents sweeping administrative access to multiple OPM systems containing personally identifiable information, often without proper vetting or training, and in violation of both Privacy Act restrictions and OPM’s own established cybersecurity protocols. The court determined that these actions constituted unlawful disclosures and a failure to maintain appropriate safeguards, and that the risk of further harm, including cybersecurity breaches, was ongoing and irreparable. The court also found that injunctive relief was in the public interest and not outweighed by the government’s interest in IT modernization, since such modernization could be achieved without violating privacy laws.

The court’s order required OPM to report on post-March 2025 procedures to ensure compliance with the Privacy Act, barred further unauthorized disclosures to DOGE agents, and mandated the establishment of proper security safeguards. The order was administratively stayed for fourteen days and conditioned on the posting of a bond by the plaintiffs. The court retained jurisdiction to enforce the injunction and required continued reporting by OPM.

No trial has occurred, and, as of the preliminary injunction, no court-appointed monitor or special master has been assigned. The court’s opinion reflects that the case is part of a broader set of related cases nationwide challenging DOGE-related access to sensitive federal personnel data, several of which have resulted in similar preliminary relief.

No final settlement or consent decree has been reached, and no disputes over settlement enforcement are noted in the record to date. The case remains ongoing.
results.46095:
This case concerns a legal challenge by a coalition of prominent research universities, academic associations, and universities (including public and private institutions) to a sudden policy change by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) regarding the reimbursement of indirect costs, also known as facilities and administration (F&A) costs, on federal research grants. The case was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts on February 10, 2025, immediately after the NIH, part of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), issued a Supplemental Guidance (NOT-OD-25-068) on February 7, 2025. This guidance imposed an across-the-board 15% cap on indirect cost reimbursements for all existing and future NIH grants to institutions of higher education, superseding previously negotiated rates that were typically much higher and tailored to each institution.

The Plaintiffs include several major higher education associations (the Association of American Universities, the American Council on Education, and the Association of Public and Land-grant Universities), as well as numerous universities such as Brandeis, Brown, the Regents of the University of California, Caltech, Carnegie Mellon, the University of Chicago, Cornell, George Washington University, Johns Hopkins, MIT, the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Rochester, and Tufts. The Defendants are HHS, NIH, and their respective acting officials. Plaintiffs were represented by private counsel from Jenner & Block LLP and Clement & Murphy PLLC.

Plaintiffs claimed that the NIH’s action violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), relevant federal appropriations statutes—specifically, Section 224 of the Further Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2024—and the governing federal grant regulations (45 C.F.R. § 75.414 and related provisions). They asserted that the new guidance was issued without statutory authority, was arbitrary and capricious, failed to follow legally required procedures such as notice-and-comment rulemaking, and unlawfully applied retroactively to existing grants. Plaintiffs sought a nationwide injunction barring enforcement of the new 15% cap and restoration of the prior negotiated rates.

The case was heard by Judge Angel Kelley. Plaintiffs moved immediately for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction to prevent imminent harm, citing the risk of disruption to ongoing and future research, loss of jobs, and threats to clinical trials and infrastructure due to drastic and immediate cuts in grant funding. The Court granted emergency relief, maintaining the status quo while the matter was fully briefed and argued.

After full briefing and a hearing, the Court found for the Plaintiffs. The Court held that it had jurisdiction under the APA and was not barred by the Tucker Act, as the claims were rooted in statutes and regulations, not contract. The Court determined that the NIH’s guidance violated both the plain language of the relevant regulations and the 2024 appropriations rider, which explicitly prohibited NIH from imposing across-the-board caps or modified reimbursement approaches for indirect costs. The Court found that the agency failed to provide a reasoned explanation, disregarded long-standing reliance interests of research institutions, failed to follow required notice-and-comment procedures, and retroactively impaired rights under existing grants in violation of administrative law.

On March 5, 2025, the Court issued a nationwide preliminary injunction barring NIH and HHS from implementing, applying, or enforcing the 15% cap guidance for any current or future grants. The injunction was later converted, with the parties’ assent, into a permanent injunction with final judgment entered April 4, 2025. The judgment vacated the NIH guidance in full and ordered the agencies not to enforce it. The Court held that the rulemaking was unlawful on multiple grounds, including violation of APA procedural requirements, lack of statutory authority, and arbitrary and capricious agency action.

The NIH and HHS, through the Department of Justice, timely appealed the final judgment and permanent injunction to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. As of the date of final judgment, the challenged 15% cap remains unenforceable nationwide, and the prior negotiated indirect cost rates must be honored for all NIH grants.

This lawsuit was filed on February 3, 2025, in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia by three organizations—Alliance for Retired Americans, the American Federation of Government Employees, AFL-CIO, and the Service Employees International Union, AFL-CIO—each representing large memberships of retirees and federal employees. The defendants are the Secretary of the Treasury (in his official capacity), the Department of the Treasury, and its Bureau of the Fiscal Service (Bureau). Plaintiffs are represented by private counsel, including Public Citizen Litigation Group and the State Democracy Defenders Fund.

Plaintiffs allege that the Department of the Treasury unlawfully granted members of the so-called “Department of Government Efficiency” (DOGE)—a federal initiative established by executive order in January 2025 and associated with USDS (United States DOGE Service) and Elon Musk—unfettered access to the Bureau’s systems and records. These systems contain sensitive personal and financial information of millions of individuals, including federal employees, retirees, Social Security recipients, and taxpayers, all of whom must interact with the federal government for payments, collections, and benefits. Plaintiffs claim that this access was provided without following the requirements of the Privacy Act of 1974 and the Internal Revenue Code, which restrict disclosure and use of personal and tax data, and without the proper notice or safeguards required by law.

The legal basis for the case is the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), under which plaintiffs assert that the Treasury’s actions are contrary to law, arbitrary and capricious, and in excess of statutory authority. Specifically, plaintiffs claim that the Bureau’s disclosure of information to DOGE members violated the Privacy Act’s restrictions on disclosure of records and failed to comply with the Act’s requirements for altering systems of records or expanding access. Plaintiffs also allege violations of the Internal Revenue Code’s confidentiality provisions regarding taxpayer data. Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief, including an order prohibiting further disclosure of personal and financial information to DOGE or its affiliates and requiring the Treasury to comply with federal privacy laws.

Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly is presiding over the case. Early in the litigation, the parties agreed to a consent order temporarily restricting access to the Bureau’s payment systems, limiting it to certain Treasury employees and DOGE Team members on a “read-only” basis, with additional limitations as the case developed. The court held an evidentiary hearing and converted plaintiffs’ motion for a temporary restraining order into a motion for preliminary injunction. The court denied the preliminary injunction, ruling that plaintiffs had not shown a likelihood of irreparable harm under the D.C. Circuit’s standard, but found that the plaintiffs had plausibly alleged standing and that the court had subject-matter jurisdiction.

The case has not been consolidated with other litigation, but the court and parties referenced related cases in other federal jurisdictions with overlapping issues regarding DOGE access to federal systems. The court ordered production of the administrative record and permitted limited, expedited discovery focused on the details of how DOGE access was implemented and controlled at the Treasury.

Both sides have now moved for summary judgment. Defendants argue that plaintiffs lack standing, that no final agency action is at issue, that the APA does not permit this type of prospective injunctive relief for alleged Privacy Act or Internal Revenue Code violations, and that, in any event, Treasury employees’ access was lawful, appropriately limited, and not arbitrary or capricious. Plaintiffs counter that the agency’s actions were a marked and unlawful departure from legal privacy protections and agency procedures, and that the access provided to DOGE was not justified by any legitimate or well-defined agency purpose.

No trial has been scheduled. As of this summary, the court has not yet ruled on the cross-motions for summary judgment. No final decree or settlement has been reached; thus, there are no ongoing court-ordered terms, monitoring, or settlement enforcement at this stage.

The factual basis for the case centers on the accelerated implementation of the DOGE initiative at the Treasury Department after the 2025 presidential inauguration, the removal of senior Bureau personnel who resisted DOGE access, and the subsequent provision of broad, ongoing access to the Bureau’s payment systems—containing names, Social Security numbers, bank account information, and other sensitive data—without public notice, the required privacy documentation, or individual consent. Plaintiffs allege that, as a result, their members’ privacy rights under federal law have been systematically compromised, and they seek court intervention to halt further unauthorized disclosures.
results.46563:
This case, filed on May 2, 2025, in the Western District of Washington, involves a coalition of cities, counties, and local agencies challenging the federal government's imposition of new conditions on federal grant funding. The plaintiffs include major cities and counties (such as King County, New York City, San Francisco, Boston, and others), local transit agencies, airport authorities, and housing authorities. These plaintiffs rely on substantial annual federal funding—amounting to billions of dollars—distributed through the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) and the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT), including DOT’s operating administrations: the Federal Transit Administration (FTA), Federal Highway Administration (FHWA), Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), and Federal Railroad Administration (FRA). The plaintiffs are represented by a combination of private counsel, local government attorneys, and legal non-profits.

The case is not a class action but involves a broad coalition of local government entities and agencies with significant reliance on federal grants for homelessness assistance, public transit, transportation infrastructure, and airport improvements. The defendants are federal agencies and their heads, sued in their official capacities.

The lawsuit centers on a series of executive orders and policy directives issued by President Trump beginning in January 2025, after his inauguration. These orders direct federal agencies to attach new and expansive conditions to federal grants—conditions that were not included in the original Notices of Funding Opportunity (NOFOs), were not authorized by Congress, and, according to plaintiffs, are not germane to the statutory purposes of the grant programs. The challenged conditions include requirements that recipients:

- Certify they do not operate any programs promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives, interpreting federal nondiscrimination law as broadly prohibiting all forms of DEI.
- Cooperate with federal immigration enforcement and not “abet” sanctuary policies or facilitate illegal immigration, including using specific federal systems to verify immigration status.
- Not use grant funds to “promote gender ideology,” as defined in an executive order that adopts a restrictive and exclusionary understanding of gender identity.
- Not use grant funds to “promote elective abortion,” going beyond the Hyde Amendment’s actual statutory restrictions.
- Agree that compliance with these policies is “material” to payment decisions for purposes of the False Claims Act, exposing recipients to potential treble damages and penalties.
- Comply with “all current Executive Orders,” effectively importing future policy changes into grant requirements.

Plaintiffs allege these federal conditions are not authorized by the statutes governing the grants (such as the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act for HUD’s Continuum of Care program and multiple statutes for DOT’s programs), and that they are unconstitutionally vague, violate the Spending Clause and Tenth Amendment (by being coercive and unrelated to the grants’ purposes), and contravene the separation of powers. Plaintiffs further allege that the conditions violate the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) as arbitrary and capricious, contrary to law, and imposed without required procedures.

Judge Barbara J. Rothstein presides over the case. Early in the litigation, plaintiffs sought and obtained a temporary restraining order (TRO) and, subsequently, preliminary injunctions against enforcement of the challenged conditions. The court found subject-matter jurisdiction and concluded that the claims did not sound in contract (and thus were not subject to the Tucker Act’s exclusive jurisdiction for contract claims against the federal government). The court determined that the source of the rights asserted was the Constitution and federal statutes, and that plaintiffs sought equitable relief to prevent unlawful conditions on grants, not damages or specific performance.

The court granted injunctive relief, finding that plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits, that the new conditions likely exceeded the agencies’ statutory and constitutional authority, and that the conditions were unrelated to the programs’ purposes and imposed ambiguous, coercive, and vague requirements. The court also found irreparable harm, reasoning that local governments faced an impossible choice between accepting unconstitutional conditions or losing essential funding, with devastating consequences for homelessness services, transportation, and public safety. The court’s orders enjoined HUD, DOT, and their operating administrations from imposing or enforcing the challenged conditions, from withholding or conditioning funds based on those terms, and from requiring certifications related to those conditions. The court declined to require plaintiffs to post a bond.

After the initial injunction, additional plaintiffs joined the case, including more cities, counties, and local agencies. The court extended the preliminary injunction to these new plaintiffs and to additional DOT programs as the agencies expanded the challenged conditions across their entire grant portfolio. No trial has yet occurred, and there are no reported opinions beyond the preliminary injunction decisions. The federal government has appealed the preliminary injunction to the Ninth Circuit.

No class has been certified. There is no court-appointed monitor, and no settlement or consent decree has been reached as of the date of the most recent filings. The case remains active, with the preliminary injunction in effect pending further orders or appellate review.

The factual basis of the case is that the new federal grant conditions, imposed abruptly and without notice, threaten to withhold or disrupt billions of dollars in funding for vital local public services, with the effect of coercing local governments to implement federal policy directives unrelated to the purpose of the funded programs. Plaintiffs detailed the immediate and long-term harms to their residents, including risks to public safety, housing stability, and critical infrastructure, should the challenged conditions be enforced.
results.46484:
On April 23, 2025, a legal services organization representing the interests of legal professionals filed suit in federal court against the U.S. Department of Justice and two high-ranking officials in their official capacities. The case arose after the Department of Justice, following public criticism by the organization of the presidential administration and its recent participation in a lawsuit against the federal government, issued a memorandum barring DOJ employees from participating in that organization’s events during official time. The next day, DOJ terminated a series of grants to the organization’s commission that provided training and assistance for legal professionals working with victims of domestic and sexual violence. DOJ offered only a brief explanation, stating that the grants “no longer effectuate agency priorities,” but did not terminate similar grants to other organizations.

The organization alleged that this termination was unlawful retaliation for engaging in protected First Amendment activities, including public advocacy and the filing of litigation. Additional claims were brought under the First and Fifth Amendments (including viewpoint discrimination, unconstitutional conditions, and due process and equal protection violations), as well as under the Administrative Procedure Act. The organization sought declaratory and injunctive relief—specifically, an order barring DOJ from enforcing or otherwise giving effect to the grant terminations, preventing reallocation of the grant funds, and requiring DOJ to process the grants in the customary manner and timeframe.

The organization was represented by private counsel from a nonprofit legal services group. The case was assigned to Judge Christopher R. Cooper.

Shortly after filing, the organization moved for a temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction. The court scheduled expedited briefing and a hearing. DOJ did not contest that the organization’s speech was protected or that similar grants to other groups continued, but argued primarily that the court lacked jurisdiction under the Tucker Act and that the case belonged in the Court of Federal Claims.

On May 14, 2025, Judge Cooper issued a memorandum opinion and order granting the organization’s motion for a preliminary injunction on its First Amendment retaliation claim. The court held that the claim arose from the Constitution, not the grant contract, and thus federal question jurisdiction was proper. The court found the evidence strongly suggested DOJ terminated the grants as retaliation for protected First Amendment activity, noting the close temporal proximity between the DOJ memorandum and the grant cancellations, the lack of performance issues with the grants, and the disparate treatment of this organization compared to other grantees. The court found the organization would suffer irreparable harm absent an injunction, including the loss of First Amendment rights and the imminent shutdown of critical victim services. The court enjoined DOJ from enforcing the grant terminations or reallocating the funds, but did not require reinstatement of grants that had already expired by their terms, nor did it bar DOJ from terminating the grants for valid, nonretaliatory reasons in the future.

As of July 2025, the case remains administratively closed pending further status updates, with the preliminary injunction in effect. No trial has taken place, no settlement has been reached, and no appeals have been docketed. The only reported opinion is the May 14, 2025 memorandum opinion granting the preliminary injunction (2025 WL [not provided]). The court has retained jurisdiction to enforce its order. The underlying facts establish that DOJ’s stated reason for terminating the grants was likely pretextual, and the actual motivation was the organization’s protected advocacy and litigation activity.
results.46279:
This case is a certified nationwide class action challenging the U.S. Department of Homeland Security’s (DHS) policy and practice of removing noncitizens with final orders of removal to third countries—countries not previously designated during immigration proceedings—without first providing them with meaningful notice or a real opportunity to seek protection from removal to those countries based on fear of persecution or torture. The lawsuit was filed on March 23, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.

**Parties:**  
The plaintiffs are a group of noncitizens subject to final removal orders, all of whom had been ordered removed to a particular country (often their country of origin) and, in some cases, granted protection from removal to that country due to risk of persecution or torture. Plaintiffs act on behalf of a class of similarly situated individuals—those who, on or after February 18, 2025, have been or will be removed to a country not previously designated for removal and not identified in writing in prior proceedings. The defendants are the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and its Secretary, the U.S. Attorney General, and the Superintendent of Plymouth County Correctional Facility. Plaintiffs are represented by private immigration and civil rights counsel, including the National Immigration Litigation Alliance, Northwest Immigrant Rights Project, and Human Rights First.

**Legal Foundation:**  
Plaintiffs bring claims under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), specifically 8 U.S.C. § 1231(b)(3), the Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act of 1998 (FARRA) (implementing the Convention Against Torture), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment. They allege that DHS’s policy or practice of deporting class members to third countries without advance written notice or a meaningful opportunity to apply for protection violates statutory, regulatory, and constitutional guarantees against removal to countries where they would face persecution or torture. Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief, including setting aside DHS’s policy and requiring notice and an opportunity to be heard before any removal to a third country.

**Factual Basis:**  
Plaintiffs allege that, starting in early 2025, DHS implemented a directive to review noncitizens with final removal orders for possible re-detention and removal to third countries, including countries that had not been designated during prior removal proceedings. Under DHS’s policy, if the United States has received “diplomatic assurances” from a third country that it will not persecute or torture removed individuals, DHS may remove a person there without further process. In cases without such assurances, DHS provides only minimal notice (sometimes as little as 6-24 hours), does not affirmatively inquire about fear of removal, and, if a person raises a fear, conducts a summary screening within 24 hours. Plaintiffs and class members have been removed to countries such as Mexico, El Salvador, and South Sudan under this policy—sometimes without any notice, or with notice only as removal is occurring, and without opportunity to present a fear-based claim to an immigration judge.

**Proceedings and Rulings:**  
Early in the case, the court granted a temporary restraining order and, after further proceedings, certified the class and granted a preliminary injunction. The court found that DHS’s policy likely violates the INA, CAT, and due process, and ordered DHS to provide written notice (in a language the noncitizen understands, and to counsel if any) and a meaningful opportunity to raise a fear-based claim for protection before any removal to a third country. If a “reasonable fear” is found, DHS must move to reopen proceedings for an immigration judge to hear the claim; if not, the person must be given fifteen days to seek reopening. The court further clarified that “meaningful opportunity” required at least ten days’ advance notice.

DHS sought to remove class members to third countries (including Libya and South Sudan), sometimes without complying with the court’s order. Plaintiffs moved for emergency relief to halt these removals. The court found that DHS had violated the preliminary injunction by removing class members to South Sudan with less than 24 hours’ notice and no meaningful opportunity to be heard, and ordered additional remedial measures.

**Appellate Proceedings:**  
DHS appealed the preliminary injunction to the First Circuit, which denied a stay pending appeal. DHS then sought emergency relief from the Supreme Court, which stayed the preliminary injunction pending appeal and any petition for certiorari. As a result, the preliminary relief is not currently in effect, but the district court’s remedial order regarding the South Sudan removals remains in force for those individuals.

**Policy Documents and Further Developments:**  
During the litigation, DHS issued policy memoranda confirming its process for third-country removals, which allow removal based on diplomatic assurances or minimal notice and do not require affirmative inquiry into fear or a robust opportunity to seek protection. Plaintiffs’ ongoing summary judgment motion seeks a declaratory judgment that this policy violates statutory and constitutional requirements.

**Judge Information:**  
The case is presided over by Judge Brian E. Murphy.

**Related Cases:**  
The court and parties referenced related litigation regarding third-country removals and withholding protections, including recent Supreme Court and First Circuit decisions on related jurisdictional and statutory issues.

**Status:**  
The class action remains pending. The preliminary injunction is stayed pending appellate review, but the district court continues to supervise compliance with its remedial orders and discovery regarding alleged violations. Plaintiffs’ summary judgment motion and other procedural matters are currently before the court, with further proceedings stayed pending appellate resolution of the preliminary injunction.
results.46186:
On February 28, 2025, a group of individual noncitizens, U.S. sponsors, and a nonprofit organization filed a class action in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts challenging actions by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and related agencies under the Trump administration. The case centers on the federal government’s abrupt termination and suspension of several humanitarian parole programs that had previously allowed noncitizens from Ukraine, Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua, Venezuela, Afghanistan, and certain other countries to enter or remain in the United States for urgent humanitarian reasons or significant public benefit, pursuant to 8 U.S.C. § 1182(d)(5)(A).

The plaintiffs include individuals who entered the U.S. under these parole programs (such as Ukrainians fleeing the Russian invasion, Central Americans escaping persecution, and Afghans evacuated after U.S. withdrawal), U.S. citizens who served as sponsors for such parolees or sought family reunification, and the Haitian Bridge Alliance, a nonprofit providing support to Haitian migrants. The class action was brought with the assistance of private counsel and nonprofit legal organizations.

The complaint alleges that, immediately upon assuming office on January 20, 2025, President Trump issued executive orders directing the Secretary of Homeland Security to terminate all “categorical parole programs,” specifically referencing the programs for Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans, and Venezuelans (“CHNV”). Acting Secretary Benjamine Huffman and other DHS officials then issued memoranda and directives pausing, terminating, or refusing to adjudicate applications for parole, re-parole, or other immigration benefits (such as asylum, Temporary Protected Status, and adjustment of status) for individuals who entered the U.S. through several parole programs, including Uniting for Ukraine (U4U), Operation Allies Welcome (OAW) for Afghans, Family Reunification Parole (FRP), Military Parole in Place (MPIP), and Central American Minors (CAM).

On March 25, 2025, DHS published a Federal Register notice formally terminating the CHNV parole processes and ordering that, as of April 24, 2025, all outstanding grants of parole and related work authorization for CHNV parolees would be ended unless the Secretary provided individualized relief. The stated justification included a shift in administration policy and concerns about vetting and fraud, but the notice applied categorically to all affected parolees. DHS also suspended the adjudication of all pending immigration benefit applications for parolees from these programs, citing security vetting reviews.

Plaintiffs alleged these actions violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) as arbitrary and capricious, contrary to law, and in excess of statutory authority; that they violated the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment; and that they failed to comply with required agency procedures for notice of termination. The suit sought declaratory and injunctive relief restoring the status quo, resuming parole and benefit adjudications, and prohibiting the mass termination of parole or work authorization without individual review.

Judge Indira Talwani presides over the case. The court certified a class encompassing all individuals who received parole through the affected programs and had pending applications for re-parole or other immigration benefits, as well as U.S.-based supporters with pending sponsorship applications. On April 14, 2025, the court granted a preliminary injunction and class-wide stay preventing DHS from implementing its mass truncation of CHNV parole and related work authorization for existing parolees, pending further order. The court also stayed the indefinite suspension of re-parole and benefit adjudications for class members under the other parole programs.

The government appealed to the First Circuit, which denied the government’s motion for a stay pending appeal. The U.S. Supreme Court then granted the government’s application for a stay, allowing DHS to proceed with the mass termination of CHNV parolees’ status and work authorization while the appeal and any petition for certiorari are pending.

Defendants have since filed a motion to dismiss, arguing that the court lacks subject matter jurisdiction due to the discretionary nature of parole decisions and challenging the plaintiffs’ standing. The government asserts that the actions taken were within its statutory discretion and do not violate the APA or the Constitution.

The case remains pending, with the central issues now including whether DHS’s categorical termination of parole and suspension of benefit adjudications—without individualized review—is lawful or violates federal statutes and constitutional protections. No trial has been held, and there have been no reported opinions apart from the preliminary injunction and class certification orders. Appeals and further proceedings are ongoing.
results.46180:
On February 25, 2025, three organizations representing educators and sociologists—the American Federation of Teachers (AFT), American Federation of Teachers–Maryland (AFT-MD), and the American Sociological Association (ASA)—filed suit in the District of Maryland, later joined by Eugene School District 4J from Oregon. Plaintiffs were represented by private public interest counsel. The defendants were the U.S. Department of Education (DOE) and senior DOE officials sued in their official capacities.

The case arose after DOE issued a “Dear Colleague Letter” (the Letter) on February 14, 2025, which purported to clarify educational institutions’ obligations under Title VI of the Civil Rights Act and the Equal Protection Clause in the wake of the Supreme Court’s 2023 decision in Students for Fair Admissions v. Harvard (SFFA). The Letter declared that a wide range of activities—such as classroom teaching about systemic and structural racism, support for diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) programs, and race-conscious admissions or support programs—were newly interpreted as potentially unlawful discrimination. It warned that DOE would begin enforcement based on this interpretation, including the possible loss of federal funding for noncompliance. The Letter was accompanied by FAQs and a new “End DEI” reporting portal soliciting complaints about DEI-related activities.

In April 2025, DOE took a further step by requiring every state and local education agency (SEA and LEA) to sign a Certification affirming compliance with this new interpretation of Title VI and SFFA as a condition of receiving federal funds, threatening funding termination, breach of contract, and False Claims Act (FCA) liability for “illegal DEI” practices. The Certification was sent out on April 3, 2025, with a short compliance deadline.

Plaintiffs alleged that both the Letter and the Certification Requirement imposed vague, overbroad, and viewpoint-discriminatory new requirements on educational institutions and teachers—chilling lawful speech and association, disrupting curriculum, and placing federal funding at risk. They argued these agency actions violated the First Amendment (free speech and association), the Fifth Amendment (due process vagueness), and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) for being arbitrary and capricious, contrary to law and the Constitution, in excess of statutory authority, and issued without required notice-and-comment rulemaking. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including vacatur of both the Letter and the Certification.

Judge Stephanie A. Gallagher presided. After initially granting a preliminary stay of the Letter (April 24, 2025), the court allowed the case to continue on summary judgment following amendment of the complaint to include Certification-related claims. Other related cases were pending in the Districts of New Hampshire and Columbia, which also issued preliminary injunctions against the Letter and Certification.

On August 14, 2025, the court granted summary judgment for the plaintiffs on all claims except one (denying only a facial overbreadth challenge to the Certification), and for the government on that single count. The court found that both the Letter and the Certification were final agency actions and legislative rules that had been issued without notice-and-comment, in violation of the APA. The court held that DOE failed to consider the facts, law, reliance interests, or the Paperwork Reduction Act in promulgating the Certification. Both actions were found to be arbitrary and capricious, not in accordance with law, in excess of statutory authority (including the Department of Education Organization Act’s bar on federal control of curriculum), and contrary to constitutional rights—particularly the First Amendment (for content and viewpoint-based restrictions on classroom speech) and the Fifth Amendment (for vagueness).

The court VACATED both the Dear Colleague Letter and the Certification Requirement nationwide under the APA, restoring the legal status quo and precluding DOE from enforcing the challenged interpretations. No further injunctive or declaratory relief was ordered, as vacatur was held to provide complete relief. No administrative record was filed; no trial occurred. The court’s ruling follows multiple reported opinions and is final as of August 14, 2025.
results.46119:
This case arises from the actions of the Department of Government Efficiency (“DOGE”), a newly established federal entity created by President Trump on January 20, 2025, and led in practice by Elon Musk. DOGE’s stated purpose is to implement the President’s agenda of government efficiency, but the plaintiffs allege that its activities have gone far beyond this, resulting in the effective dismantling of the United States Agency for International Development (“USAID”). USAID, an independent executive agency created by Congress, is responsible for civilian foreign aid and development programs.
