The case was initially filed on February 13, 2025, by a group of current and former USAID employees and contractors (who have proceeded anonymously due to safety and reputational concerns), supported by private and public interest counsel. The plaintiffs are individuals who, as of January 20, 2025, worked for USAID in various capacities, including civil service, Foreign Service, Foreign Service Limited, and as personal services contractors (PSCs). They seek to represent a class comprising all similarly situated USAID personnel employed or contracted during the relevant period.

The core legal claims are that: (1) Elon Musk, as de facto head of DOGE, exercised significant governmental authority over USAID without proper appointment under the Appointments Clause of Article II of the U.S. Constitution; and (2) the collective actions of DOGE and associated federal officials violated the Constitution’s separation of powers by dismantling a congressionally created agency without statutory authority or congressional consent. The complaint details that between January and March 2025, DOGE personnel—acting at Musk’s direction—gained unrestricted access to USAID’s systems, placed senior officials on administrative leave, ordered or initiated mass contract and grant terminations, physically closed USAID’s headquarters, erased digital infrastructure, and began large-scale reductions in force, often without warning, due process, or legal authority. The complaint further alleges that these actions caused plaintiffs and class members loss of employment or contract status, loss of access to work systems, disclosure of sensitive personal and professional data, reputational harm, and emotional distress.

The government, represented by the Department of Justice, moved to dismiss the action, arguing that claims by employees must be resolved through the Civil Service Reform Act and those by contractors through the Contract Disputes Act, and challenging the plaintiffs’ standing. The government also contends that the alleged harms are not traceable to Musk or DOGE, as lawful agency officials ultimately approved the challenged actions. The government further asserts that Musk was merely an advisor, not an “officer” under the Appointments Clause, and that any alleged overreach is, at most, a statutory rather than constitutional violation.

The case was assigned to Judge Theodore D. Chuang. On March 18, 2025, the district court issued a preliminary injunction, finding plaintiffs likely to succeed on the merits of both their Appointments Clause and separation of powers claims, and halting further actions by DOGE and Musk to dismantle USAID. The government appealed, and the Fourth Circuit stayed the injunction pending appeal, highlighting the lack of proper defendants in the original complaint. Plaintiffs then amended the complaint to add USAID, the State Department, President Trump, and key agency officials as defendants, and clarified the status of each named plaintiff as employee or PSC.

The plaintiffs have moved for class certification for all persons employed by USAID—including PSCs—since January 20, 2025, seeking only declaratory and injunctive relief. They seek (1) a declaration that Musk’s and DOGE’s activities at USAID violate the Appointments Clause; (2) a declaration that the dismantling of USAID violates separation of powers principles; (3) an order setting aside all actions taken to unlawfully reorganize or eliminate USAID; and (4) an injunction barring further such actions absent congressional authorization. The government’s motion to dismiss and the class certification motion are currently pending before the district court. The Fourth Circuit has held the appeal in abeyance pending resolution of the motion to dismiss or other appealable orders.

The factual basis for the case includes detailed allegations of DOGE and Musk’s direct involvement in mass employment actions, contract and grant terminations, system shutdowns, and public statements disparaging USAID and its staff, all allegedly outside statutory and constitutional bounds. The complaint also alleges that these actions have severely disrupted USAID’s statutory missions and caused ongoing harm to the plaintiffs, the class, and the public interest. No trial has occurred, and the case is at the motion stage, with discovery contested and not yet underway. There are related cases pending in other courts, including actions by unions and PSC associations raising similar issues. No decree, settlement, or final judgment has been entered as of the date of this summary.
results.46099:
On February 10, 2025, several nonprofit organizations that receive federal foreign assistance—including the AIDS Vaccine Advocacy Coalition, Journalism Development Network, and the Center for Victims of Torture—filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the U.S. Department of State, USAID, the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), the President, and senior agency officials. These organizations challenged a series of Executive Branch actions, beginning with President Trump’s Executive Order No. 14169 (issued January 20, 2025), which directed an immediate, government-wide “pause” on foreign aid obligations and disbursements for review of alignment with “America First” foreign policy. Agency heads, including the Secretary of State and USAID, implemented the order by issuing blanket stop-work orders and suspending or terminating thousands of existing foreign assistance grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements.

Plaintiffs were represented by private counsel from Public Citizen Litigation Group. They alleged that the funding freeze and subsequent mass terminations of foreign assistance awards exceeded the President’s constitutional authority, violated the Take Care Clause, violated the separation of powers, and violated various federal statutes, including the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Impoundment Control Act, the Anti-Deficiency Act, and provisions of the Further Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2024. Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to restore the flow of funds, prohibit “unlawful impoundment” of appropriated funds, and reinstate terminated awards.

The case was assigned to Judge Amir H. Ali. On February 13, 2025, Judge Ali granted a temporary restraining order (TRO) in part, enjoining agency defendants (but not the President) from enforcing the blanket funding freeze and suspending payments or issuing new terminations for preexisting awards. The court subsequently enforced compliance with the TRO despite continuing noncompliance by defendants, and denied motions by the government to stay the orders pending appeal.

After expedited briefing and hearings, on March 10, 2025, the district court issued a preliminary injunction. The court held that plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims that the blanket suspension of foreign aid was arbitrary and capricious under the APA and, separately, that the Executive’s impoundment of appropriated foreign aid funds—without following statutory procedures for rescission or deferral—violated the separation of powers. The injunction required defendants to lift the freeze, reinstate payments for work completed before February 13, 2025, and “make available for obligation the full amount of funds that Congress appropriated for foreign assistance programs.” The court found that continued impoundment threatened the existence of the plaintiff organizations and caused severe humanitarian harm worldwide.

Defendants appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit, which expedited briefing. On August 13, 2025, a divided panel of the D.C. Circuit (Judge Henderson writing, Judge Pan dissenting) vacated the preliminary injunction as it related to the obligation of appropriated funds. The Court of Appeals held that the plaintiffs lacked a cause of action to enforce the Impoundment Control Act or appropriations statutes. The court reasoned that claims challenging impoundment by the Executive must proceed through the statutory mechanism Congress created: the Comptroller General may bring an enforcement suit, but private grantees may not. The court further held that the plaintiffs could not reframe their statutory claims as constitutional separation-of-powers claims given the Supreme Court’s decision in Dalton v. Specter, and that ultra vires review was unavailable in this context. The panel recognized that plaintiffs had standing, but determined the absence of a cause of action was fatal to their requested relief.

Thus, the D.C. Circuit vacated the injunctive relief requiring the Executive to obligate the full amount of appropriated foreign aid funds, remanding for further proceedings. As of the most recent filings, the district court’s permanent resolution of the case—including the disposition of plaintiffs’ amended claims and motions to enforce the injunction—remains pending, with further proceedings likely to be shaped by the appellate decision.
results.46093:
This case concerns the Trump Administration’s actions to suspend the U.S. Refugee Admissions Program (USRAP) and defund its resettlement infrastructure, challenged by a group of refugees, U.S.-based family members, and national and local resettlement organizations. The lawsuit was filed on February 10, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington. The plaintiffs include individual refugees abroad who were in the final stages of resettlement, U.S. citizens seeking to reunite with family members through the follow-to-join (FTJ) program, refugees recently arrived in the country, and three nonprofit resettlement agencies (HIAS, Inc., Church World Service, Inc., and Lutheran Community Services Northwest). The defendants are the President of the United States (Donald J. Trump, in his official capacity), and the Secretaries of State, Homeland Security, and Health and Human Services, all sued in their official capacities. Plaintiffs are represented by private counsel and attorneys from the International Refugee Assistance Project (IRAP) and Perkins Coie LLP.

Shortly after taking office for a second term, President Trump issued Executive Order 14163 (“Refugee Ban EO”) on January 20, 2025, suspending all refugee admissions under USRAP and all decisions on pending refugee applications indefinitely, subject to periodic review but with no firm timeline for resuming admissions. The stated justifications concerned national security, assimilation, and the impact of migration on U.S. communities, but the EO did not cite evidence that USRAP admissions caused these issues.

Federal agencies immediately implemented the EO by halting refugee processing, canceling scheduled travel (even for refugees with imminent departures), and freezing all new USRAP admissions. The Department of State also suspended all funding for USRAP-related cooperative agreements to national and local resettlement agencies, instructing them to stop work, cancel obligations, and lay off staff. This funding suspension included support for overseas case processing, initial resettlement services, and post-arrival assistance for recent refugees and Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) holders. On February 26, 2025, after the district court’s first preliminary injunction, the government escalated by terminating all R&P (reception and placement) and most processing-related cooperative agreements with resettlement partners, thereby threatening the collapse of the USRAP infrastructure.

Plaintiffs alleged that these actions violated the Refugee Act of 1980, the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Accardi doctrine (requiring agencies to follow their own rules), the U.S. Constitution (Fifth Amendment due process and separation of powers), and exceeded the President’s statutory authority under 8 U.S.C. § 1182(f). They sought declaratory and injunctive relief to bar enforcement of the EO, halt the funding suspensions and terminations, and require restoration of USRAP operations and benefits.

The case was assigned to Judge Jamal N. Whitehead. On February 25, 2025, after expedited briefing, the court granted a preliminary injunction, finding plaintiffs likely to succeed on the merits, that the President’s actions unlawfully nullified Congress’s statutory refugee program, and that the agencies’ implementation and funding suspensions were arbitrary, capricious, and contrary to law under the APA. The court ordered nationwide relief, enjoining enforcement of the EO, the USRAP suspension, and funding blocks. The government’s motion to stay the injunction was denied.

The government appealed to the Ninth Circuit, which stayed the preliminary injunction in most respects but kept it in place for a narrow group: those refugees who, as of January 20, 2025, had (1) an approved refugee application authorizing conditional admission, (2) clearance from USCIS for travel, and (3) arranged and confirmable travel plans. The Ninth Circuit later clarified that only those with a “strong reliance interest” comparable to the lead plaintiff (who had sold all belongings in preparation for travel that was then canceled) were protected, and that eligibility for relief would be determined case-by-case.

The government subsequently refused to process or admit many of these refugees, arguing that new executive orders (notably a June 4, 2025, travel ban) barred entry of refugees from certain countries, despite those orders containing carveouts for refugees. Plaintiffs sought further court intervention, and the district court issued a detailed compliance framework and appointed a magistrate judge to oversee case-by-case determinations of reliance interests, but rescinded the framework after the Ninth Circuit required a narrower, individualized approach.

Meanwhile, the government moved to dismiss the case, arguing that APA review was barred or that the claims were really contract disputes over funding, and thus belonged in the Court of Federal Claims. The court denied the motion, holding that the claims were statutory and constitutional, not contractual, and that the APA provided a cause of action.

On July 30, 2025, the court certified three subclasses: (1) refugees/family members in the USRAP pipeline, (2) recently resettled refugees/SIVs within 90 days post-resettlement, and (3) FTJ petitioners. The named individual plaintiffs were appointed as subclass representatives, and IRAP and Perkins Coie as class counsel.

Throughout, the factual record described severe, compounding harm to refugees stuck abroad or separated from family, to recent arrivals denied benefits, and to resettlement agencies forced into mass layoffs and existential threats to their operations.

As of the latest filings, the case remains pending in the district court, with class certification completed and the government’s motion to dismiss denied. Implementation of the injunction, as narrowed by the Ninth Circuit, is ongoing and subject to further judicial supervision and possible special master review. Appellate proceedings and further district court status conferences continue as the parties dispute the scope of relief and compliance.
results.46065:
On February 7, 2025, the States of Washington, Oregon, and Minnesota, later joined by Colorado, along with three physician plaintiffs affiliated with Washington State’s medical institutions, filed a civil action in the Western District of Washington. They challenged the constitutionality of two executive orders issued by President Donald J. Trump in early 2025: Executive Order 14,187 (“Protecting Children from Chemical and Surgical Mutilation”) and Executive Order 14,168 (“Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government”). The lawsuits were brought against numerous federal agencies and officials, including the Departments of Health and Human Services (HHS), Justice, Defense, Education, and others, all represented by federal government counsel.

The plaintiff States operate or oversee public medical institutions and public health programs that provide gender-affirming care to transgender and gender-diverse youth and receive substantial federal research and education grants. The physician plaintiffs are pediatricians and endocrinologists who provide gender-affirming care to adolescents and are also affiliated with institutions receiving federal funds. Plaintiffs are represented by their respective state attorneys general and, in Washington, by private and assistant attorneys general.

The suit was filed as a non-class action, with the States asserting parens patriae, sovereign, and proprietary interests, and the physician plaintiffs asserting individual and third-party interests on behalf of their patients. The legal team is comprised of state attorneys general offices and, for the physicians, assistant attorneys general.

The main legal claims are that the executive orders violate the U.S. Constitution’s separation of powers by usurping Congress’s exclusive authority to appropriate funds and set grant conditions, the Fifth Amendment’s equal protection guarantee by facially discriminating against transgender and gender-diverse people and restricting medical care based on sex and gender identity, the Tenth Amendment by intruding on state regulation of medical practice, and the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause by being impermissibly vague. The plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief, including a prohibition on defendants from enforcing or implementing the challenged executive orders in the plaintiff States.

The factual basis for the case centers on the January 2025 executive orders, which directed federal agencies to immediately cut off federal research and education grants to medical institutions that provide gender-affirming care to individuals under 19, and to otherwise bar federal funds from any entity that “promotes gender ideology.” The orders also directed prioritization of criminal enforcement under 18 U.S.C. § 116 (female genital mutilation) against providers of gender-affirming care, despite the statutory inapplicability and lack of medical evidence supporting such prosecutions. The plaintiff States and their medical institutions receive hundreds of millions of dollars annually in federal funding, and enforcement of the orders threatened the loss of these funds or forced the cessation of gender-affirming care.

The case was assigned to Judge Lauren King. Plaintiffs promptly filed an emergency motion for a TRO. On February 14, 2025, Judge King granted the TRO, enjoining the defendants from enforcing Section 4 of Executive Order 14,187 (the defunding provision) and Section 8(a) (the criminal enforcement directive) within the plaintiff States. The court subsequently issued a memorandum opinion detailing its reasoning, finding that the orders likely violated the separation of powers and equal protection and would cause irreparable harm by endangering the health and well-being of transgender youth and disrupting vital medical research and care.

Defendants opposed the TRO and later the preliminary injunction, raising arguments about justiciability, interpretation of the orders, executive authority, and the nature of the medical evidence supporting gender-affirming care, but did not submit their own evidence or expert testimony.

On February 28, 2025, after briefing and oral argument, the court granted in part and denied in part the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction. The court enjoined the implementation or enforcement of Section 4 of Executive Order 14,187 and Sections 3(e) and 3(g) of Executive Order 14,168 within the plaintiff States, barring the government from conditioning or withholding federal funding on the grounds of providing gender-affirming care. The court found that the orders violated the separation of powers by unilaterally attaching new conditions to congressionally appropriated grants, and violated the Fifth Amendment by facially discriminating against transgender persons and failing heightened scrutiny. The court declined to enjoin Section 8(a) of Executive Order 14,187 because plaintiffs had not shown a credible threat of prosecution under the female genital mutilation statute.

Following the injunction, the court addressed issues of compliance, including a motion for contempt after the National Institutes of Health terminated a grant to Seattle Children’s Hospital. The court denied the contempt motion but granted expedited discovery into the reasons for the grant’s termination, later ordering defendants to correct their interpretation of the injunction’s scope regarding “gender-affirming care.” Defendants subsequently reinstated the grant.

The court set a schedule for initial disclosures and a joint status report, but later granted defendants’ motion to stay proceedings (except for preliminary injunction enforcement and related matters) pending appeal to the Ninth Circuit. The preliminary injunction remains in effect during the appeal.

No trial has occurred, and there is no class certification, settlement, or court-appointed monitor. There are related cases in other districts, notably parallel litigation in the District of Maryland resulting in a nationwide injunction, and in the District of Rhode Island. The court’s orders have been accompanied by detailed factual findings regarding the nature and efficacy of gender-affirming care, the evidence of harm to transgender youth, and the lack of congressional authorization for the executive actions challenged.
results.46028:
This case was filed on February 4, 2025, in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland. The plaintiffs include several transgender adolescents and young adults under nineteen, their parents, PFLAG, Inc. (a national nonprofit supporting LGBTQ+ families), and GLMA: Health Professionals Advancing LGBTQ+ Equality (a national nonprofit representing LGBTQ+ health professionals). The suit is brought by individual plaintiffs and not as a class action. Plaintiffs are represented by private counsel, including attorneys from the ACLU, Lambda Legal, and Jenner & Block.

The defendants are the President of the United States (in his official capacity), the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and its subagencies, key officials of HHS, the National Science Foundation (NSF), and its director. Defendants are represented by the U.S. Department of Justice.

Plaintiffs challenge two executive orders issued by President Trump in January 2025: Executive Order 14,168 (“Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government”) and Executive Order 14,187 (“Protecting Children from Chemical and Surgical Mutilation”). The first order directs federal agencies to ensure that federal funds are not used to promote “gender ideology,” while the second instructs agencies to take immediate steps to end federal research and education funding to institutions that provide gender affirming medical care to people under nineteen.

The factual basis for the case is that following these executive orders, hospitals and medical institutions across the United States abruptly stopped providing gender affirming medical care (including puberty blockers and hormone therapy) to transgender people under nineteen. Hospitals cited the risk of losing all federal funding—not just for gender affirming care but across their programs—as the reason for these shutdowns. Multiple federal agencies, including HRSA and CDC, issued notices to grantees terminating or threatening to terminate federal funding in line with the executive orders. The result was the cancellation of medical appointments and cessation of care for transgender plaintiffs and other PFLAG members. Plaintiffs and their families allege severe and immediate harm, including risks to mental and physical health, due to the sudden loss of medically necessary treatment.

Plaintiffs allege that the executive orders are unconstitutional and unlawful. They assert causes of action under the separation of powers (arguing the executive orders exceed presidential authority and violate the Appropriations, Spending, and Presentment Clauses), and under federal nondiscrimination statutes—specifically, Section 1557 of the Affordable Care Act (42 U.S.C. § 18116) and Section 1908 of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. § 300w-7), which prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex in federally funded health programs. Plaintiffs also allege violations of the Equal Protection and Due Process components of the Fifth Amendment and raise a First Amendment claim. The remedies sought include declaratory and injunctive relief prohibiting enforcement of the challenged executive orders, as well as attorneys’ fees and costs.

The case is assigned to Judge Brendan Abell Hurson. There are no consolidated or related cases noted in this record, though similar orders and litigation have proceeded in other courts.

After the complaint was filed, Plaintiffs sought emergency relief. On February 13, 2025, following a hearing, Judge Hurson granted a temporary restraining order (TRO) enjoining federal agencies from implementing or enforcing the challenged provisions of the executive orders as they relate to withholding federal funding from institutions providing gender affirming medical care to transgender patients under nineteen. Judge Hurson found Plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their claims that the orders violated the separation of powers and federal nondiscrimination statutes, and that Plaintiffs faced irreparable harm due to the loss of medical care.

On March 4, 2025, the Court issued a detailed memorandum opinion and granted a preliminary injunction extending the TRO, again enjoining HHS, its subagencies, NSF, and their officials from conditioning, withholding, or terminating federal funding based on the provision of gender affirming medical care to people under nineteen. The order required notice to all relevant federal employees and grantees and directed Defendants not to take any steps to implement or reinstate the challenged directives under any name. The Court rejected Defendants’ arguments that the orders were lawful expressions of executive power, finding that the President lacked authority to impose new funding conditions not authorized by Congress, and further determined the orders were likely to violate statutory and constitutional prohibitions against sex discrimination. On March 21, 2025, Defendants noticed an interlocutory appeal to the Fourth Circuit.

Subsequently, Plaintiffs filed an emergency motion to enforce the preliminary injunction, alleging that HHS subagencies had violated the injunction by issuing new notices threatening future funding restrictions. The Court denied the motion without prejudice, finding that, as of that time, the agencies’ communications did not constitute a clear and unequivocal violation of the injunction because they were only advisory and did not actually withhold or condition funding.

As of the most recent filings, the preliminary injunction remains in effect, and further district court proceedings are stayed pending resolution of the interlocutory appeal. No trial has been held, and there has been no settlement or consent decree. No court-appointed monitor has been assigned, and there are no ongoing monitoring reports in the record. The case remains pending on appeal.
results.46306:
This case concerns the federal government’s abrupt termination of funding for direct legal representation of unaccompanied children in immigration proceedings. On March 26, 2025, a coalition of nonprofit legal services providers—who had been funded by the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR), a division of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), through a contract administered by the Department of the Interior (DOI)—filed suit in the Northern District of California. The plaintiffs are organizations from across the United States that provide legal representation to unaccompanied children in removal proceedings or in seeking immigration relief. The government defendants are HHS, ORR, and DOI.

The plaintiffs are represented by a mix of private attorneys and nonprofit legal organizations, including the Immigrant Defenders Law Center, Amica Center for Immigrant Rights, and Justice Action Center. The case does not involve a class action; each plaintiff is a nonprofit entity that provides legal services to unaccompanied children.

The underlying facts stem from Congress’s mandate under the William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008 (TVPRA), which requires HHS to “ensure, to the greatest extent practicable,” that all unaccompanied children have counsel in legal proceedings. Since 2012, Congress has appropriated funding to support this mandate, and in 2024, ORR promulgated the “Foundational Rule” (45 C.F.R. § 410.1309(a)(4)), which directs ORR to fund legal service providers for direct representation of unaccompanied children, subject to appropriations and the impracticability of securing pro bono counsel.

On March 21, 2025, without advance notice, DOI sent a “Notice of Partial Termination for the Government’s Convenience” to Acacia Center for Justice, the prime contractor administering the program, effectively terminating all funding for direct legal representation services for unaccompanied children. The contract line items that funded direct representation, friend-of-court services, Immigrant Justice Corps fellows, and related training were all halted, leaving only “know your rights” presentations and consultations. Acacia and its network of subcontractors, including all plaintiffs, were instructed to stop work immediately on the terminated items. The government did not provide any alternative plan for ensuring representation or offer guidance for ongoing cases.

As a result, the plaintiffs alleged that thousands of unaccompanied children—many with imminent court hearings—faced loss of counsel, risking deportation or loss of legal relief for which they might qualify. Plaintiffs also faced imminent layoffs, program disruptions, and the potential inability to meet ethical duties to current clients. They sought a temporary restraining order (TRO) and preliminary injunction to require the government to continue funding representation, arguing the termination violated the TVPRA, the Foundational Rule, and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). The legal claims were based explicitly on the APA (5 U.S.C. § 706(2)), the TVPRA (8 U.S.C. § 1232(c)(5)), and the Foundational Rule.

Judge Araceli Martinez-Olguin presided over the case. On April 1, 2025, the court granted a TRO, enjoining the government from withdrawing services or funds supporting direct legal representation for unaccompanied children. The court found that the plaintiffs had standing, that the TVPRA and Foundational Rule likely imposed enforceable obligations, and that the sudden termination caused irreparable harm. The government’s arguments that the court lacked jurisdiction under the Tucker Act, or that the issue was committed to agency discretion, were rejected. The court later extended the TRO to allow for briefing on the government’s motion to recuse the judge, which was ultimately denied.

The government appealed the TRO, but the Ninth Circuit dismissed the appeal for lack of jurisdiction, finding the TRO was not appealable as a preliminary injunction. The government’s petition for rehearing en banc was also denied.

On April 29, 2025, the district court issued a preliminary injunction, again enjoining the government from withdrawing funding for direct legal representation for unaccompanied children. The court reaffirmed that the TVPRA and Foundational Rule required the government to ensure, to the greatest extent practicable, that unaccompanied children receive counsel, and that appropriations for these services remained available. The court found that the government’s termination, without ensuring representation through other means, likely violated the APA as contrary to law, in violation of its own regulations (under the Accardi doctrine), and as arbitrary and capricious agency action. The preliminary injunction was issued nationwide, as the only way to provide effective relief and maintain consistency in immigration policy.

HHS, ORR, and DOI moved for a stay of the preliminary injunction pending appeal, but the district court denied the motion. The government filed an emergency motion for a stay in the Ninth Circuit. On May 14, 2025, a Ninth Circuit panel (Judges W. Fletcher, Callahan, and Koh) denied the government’s motion for a stay pending appeal, holding that the government had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits or irreparable injury. The panel found that the APA claims were not precluded by the Tucker Act (as the legal services organizations were not in privity with the federal government and their claims were statutory, not contractual) and that the APA’s “committed to agency discretion” exception did not apply because the TVPRA and Foundational Rule imposed meaningful standards for judicial review.

Throughout the proceedings, the government maintained that the decision to terminate funding was a lawful exercise of agency discretion, that the court lacked jurisdiction under the APA and Tucker Act, and that any order to pay money under the contract would violate sovereign immunity. The court and appellate panels disagreed, finding the statutory and regulatory framework imposed enforceable duties and that withholding all funding for direct representation, with no plan to secure such representation otherwise, was unlawful.

At the time of the latest filings, the preliminary injunction remained in effect, requiring the government to maintain funding for direct legal representation for unaccompanied children nationwide, pending final judgment or further appellate action. No trial has been held or scheduled, and the case remains pending on the merits. There are no consolidated cases or appointed monitors. The litigation is ongoing, with regular status reports required regarding compliance with the injunction.
results.46201:
On March 6, 2025, eight states—California, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Colorado, Illinois, Maryland, New York, and Wisconsin—filed suit in the District of Massachusetts against the U.S. Department of Education and senior officials, seeking to challenge the Department’s abrupt termination of federal grants previously awarded under two Congressionally mandated teacher support programs: the Teacher Quality Partnership (TQP) and Supporting Effective Educator Development (SEED) programs. The states, represented by their Attorneys General, brought the case through public counsel. The lawsuit was not a class action but was brought by these state governments as individual plaintiffs.

The underlying dispute arose after a series of executive orders in January 2025 directed federal agencies to end funding for so-called "diversity, equity, and inclusion" (DEI) initiatives. In response, the Department of Education issued an internal directive on February 5, 2025, instructing staff to review and potentially terminate grants inconsistent with newly identified departmental priorities, particularly those related to DEI. Within days, the Department sent form termination letters to nearly all recipients of TQP and SEED grants, affecting over $250 million in awarded and obligated funds for teacher recruitment, training, and support across the plaintiff states. The termination letters cited 2 C.F.R. § 200.340(a)(4) as authority, asserting that the grants no longer effectuated Department priorities, but failed to specify which rationale applied to each grant or provide individualized factual findings or prior notice.

The plaintiff states alleged that the Department’s actions violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), specifically as arbitrary and capricious and not in accordance with law, because the Department failed to provide a reasoned explanation, did not consider reliance interests or individualized circumstances, relied on priorities not promulgated through required notice-and-comment procedures, and contradicted Congressional intent as reflected in the governing statutes. The states sought a declaratory judgment, vacatur of the terminations, and a temporary restraining order (TRO) and preliminary injunction to restore the status quo and prevent irreparable disruption to public education systems.

Judge Myong J. Joun granted the TRO on March 10, 2025, temporarily enjoining the Department from enforcing the terminations and restoring access to grant funds for all affected recipients in the plaintiff states. The court found a likelihood of success on the merits of the APA claims, irreparable harm to the states and their educational institutions, and that the balance of equities and public interest favored injunctive relief. The government immediately appealed to the First Circuit and sought a stay, which was denied at both the district and appellate levels. However, the Supreme Court then granted an emergency application for a stay on April 4, 2025, and construed the TRO as an appealable preliminary injunction. The Supreme Court's per curiam opinion found the states' claims to be, in essence, contract actions for money damages, and thus likely within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Court of Federal Claims under the Tucker Act, not the district court, and expressed doubt that the APA provided a waiver of sovereign immunity for the relief sought in this context. The Supreme Court also found that the risk of irretrievable payments justified a stay pending appeal.

Following the Supreme Court's intervention, the plaintiff states withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction. The First Circuit dismissed the government’s appeal as moot. In the district court, the states filed an amended complaint on June 2, 2025, reiterating their APA, statutory, constitutional, and ultra vires claims, and seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to vacate the terminations and prevent similar future actions. The Department then filed a renewed motion to dismiss or, in the alternative, to transfer the case to the Court of Federal Claims, again arguing lack of subject-matter jurisdiction under the APA and the Tucker Act.

No trial has been held, and there has been no class certification, settlement, or court-enforced decree. The litigation remains ongoing, with all parties awaiting a ruling on the government’s jurisdictional challenge to the amended complaint.

The case is captioned State of California et al. v. U.S. Department of Education et al., Case No. 1:25-cv-10548, in the District of Massachusetts. The presiding judge on current motions is District Judge Angel Kelley, following the recusal of Judge Joun. The core factual basis centers on the mass termination of Congressionally authorized teacher grant programs, the resulting disruption to state educational systems, and the legal limits on federal agency discretion to withhold or rescind previously awarded federal funds.
results.46057:
On February 6, 2025, seven individual transgender service members, an aspiring service member, and a Washington-based civil rights organization filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington, challenging the constitutionality of Executive Order No. 14183 and its implementing Department of Defense (DoD) policy (the “2025 Military Ban”). The plaintiffs are decorated, currently serving officers and enlisted personnel in the Army, Navy, and Air Force, as well as an individual seeking to enlist and an organizational plaintiff with transgender military members. The defendants are the United States, senior federal officials and entities responsible for military policy, and several military department leaders. The plaintiffs are represented by private counsel, Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, Inc., Perkins Coie LLP, and the Human Rights Campaign Foundation.

The 2025 Military Ban, issued by President Trump on January 27, 2025, and implemented by DoD Secretary Peter Hegseth, prohibits transgender people—defined as those with a current or historical diagnosis of gender dysphoria, or those who have attempted or completed gender transition—from serving in the U.S. military. The policy mandates separation of current transgender service members, rescinds prior inclusive policies, and enforces strict adherence to standards associated with birth sex (including pronouns, uniforms, facilities, and fitness requirements), regardless of gender identity. Waivers are available only under highly restrictive conditions and require proof of 36 months’ stability, no attempt to transition, and a compelling government interest in retention. There is no general exemption for those currently serving or who transitioned under prior policies.

Plaintiffs challenge the Ban under the Fifth Amendment’s Equal Protection and Due Process components, the First Amendment’s Free Speech Clause, and on equitable estoppel grounds. They allege that the Ban facially and intentionally discriminates based on transgender status and sex, penalizes and chills constitutionally protected speech and gender expression, and retroactively punishes service members who relied on earlier policies allowing open service. Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief prohibiting enforcement of the Ban and related guidance.

On March 27, 2025, following briefing, declarations, and a hearing, Judge Benjamin H. Settle granted a nationwide preliminary injunction. The court found that the Ban constituted a de facto blanket prohibition on transgender service, was not the product of meaningful military deliberation, and was unsupported by evidence of any adverse impact on readiness, cohesion, or cost. The court applied heightened scrutiny, found the government’s proffered rationales lacking, and concluded the Ban would cause irreparable harm to plaintiffs by ending military careers and denying aspiring members the opportunity to serve. The injunction restored the status quo ante—the 2021 “Austin Policy”—which permits open service by transgender individuals under consistent standards.

The government appealed to the Ninth Circuit, seeking a stay of the injunction, and also applied to the Supreme Court for a stay. Both the district court and the Ninth Circuit denied the government’s requests for a stay pending appeal, finding no showing of irreparable harm to the government. On May 6, 2025, the Supreme Court granted the government’s application for a stay, permitting enforcement of the Ban pending disposition of the appeal and any petition for certiorari.

Throughout the proceedings, the government has not pointed to evidence of harm caused by transgender service members under prior inclusive policies, and several former military officials testified that open service had no negative impacts. The case is related to parallel litigation in other districts (notably Talbott v. Trump), and the Ban represents a departure from prior policies under the Obama and Biden administrations and from an earlier, more limited ban under President Trump’s first term. The case remains pending in the district court, with proceedings stayed while the appellate process unfolds.

**Judge:**  
Judge Benjamin H. Settle is the presiding judge.

**Type of Counsel:**  
Plaintiffs are represented by private counsel (Perkins Coie LLP), Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, Inc., and Human Rights Campaign Foundation.

**Cause of Action and Statutory/Constitutional Basis:**  
Plaintiffs bring claims under the Fifth Amendment (Equal Protection and Due Process), the First Amendment (Free Speech), and equitable estoppel. No specific statutory cause of action is cited beyond the constitutional claims and 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331, 1346, and 1361 (federal question and agency action).

**Remedy Sought:**  
Declaratory judgment and preliminary and permanent injunctive relief prohibiting implementation and enforcement of the 2025 Military Ban and related guidance.

**Related Cases:**  
The case is related to Talbott v. Trump (D.D.C.), Ireland v. Hegseth (D.N.J.), and historically to Karnoski v. Trump (W.D. Wash.).

**Important Filings and Rulings:**  
- Plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction (granted March 27, 2025).
- District court nationwide preliminary injunction (March 27, 2025).
- Denial of government’s motions for a stay by the district court and Ninth Circuit.
- Supreme Court grant of stay (May 6, 2025), permitting enforcement of the Ban pending appeal.

**Factual Basis:**  
The Ban reverses nearly a decade of policy permitting open service by transgender individuals, a policy adopted after study and implemented without evidence of adverse effects. Plaintiffs are decorated and experienced service members who have served openly without incident, as corroborated by multiple former military leaders. The Ban is alleged to be motivated by animus and is unsupported by evidence of harm to military interests.

**Current Status:**  
The March 27, 2025 preliminary injunction is stayed by Supreme Court order, and enforcement of the Ban is permitted pending appeal and further proceedings. The case remains active in the district court and Ninth Circuit.
results.45984:
On January 28, 2025, a group of transgender service members and individuals seeking to join the U.S. military challenged a new executive order issued by President Donald J. Trump on January 27, 2025, that banned transgender people from serving in the military. The executive order, accompanied by additional implementation memoranda from the Department of Defense (DoD), reversed existing policies that had allowed transgender individuals to serve openly, provided they met military standards. The order stated that transgender status is incompatible with “high standards for troop readiness, lethality, cohesion, honesty, humility, uniformity, and integrity,” and directed the DoD to update its medical and retention standards to bar transgender people from enlistment and continued service. The order also required all service members to be treated according to their birth sex with respect to pronouns, grooming, housing, and access to facilities, and cancelled all transition-related medical care.

The plaintiffs are current and prospective transgender service members from multiple military branches, many with long and decorated careers. They are represented by private counsel, including civil rights and LGBTQ legal organizations. The complaint alleges that the ban and related policies violate the equal protection component of the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause, as well as procedural due process, and seeks declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent enforcement of the ban.

The case was assigned to Judge Ana C. Reyes in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. Plaintiffs promptly moved for a preliminary injunction. The DoD, following the executive order, issued implementing guidance that required the identification and administrative separation of transgender service members, and barred accession of transgender applicants. The DoD guidance included a purported waiver process, but this process was found to be effectively unavailable to transgender individuals.

The court conducted an evidentiary hearing and accepted extensive factual declarations from both sides. Plaintiffs presented evidence, including from former senior military and civilian defense officials, that transgender service members had served openly under the prior policy without incident or impairment to military readiness, and that the new ban was causing immediate and irreparable harm, including removal from active duty, cancellation of medical care, and stigmatization. Defendants argued that the policy was justified by concerns about readiness, deployability, unit cohesion, and cost, but did not produce contemporaneous evidence of actual problems caused by transgender service members under the prior policy.

On March 18, 2025, Judge Reyes granted a preliminary injunction, finding that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their equal protection claim and that the executive order and DoD guidance were likely motivated by impermissible animus toward transgender people, rather than by evidence-based military judgment. The court found that the policies facially discriminated based on sex and transgender status, and failed even rational basis review, let alone the heightened scrutiny required. The court ordered the DoD to maintain the status quo ante—continuing the policies in place prior to the Trump executive order—and to refrain from implementing the ban or any related guidance pending further order.

Defendants moved to dissolve or stay the injunction, arguing that new DoD guidance clarified that only individuals with a current diagnosis or history of gender dysphoria (as defined by the DSM-5) would be excluded, not all transgender individuals. The court denied the motion, finding that the revised guidance continued to target transgender people as a group and that the policy was not a legitimate medical regulation but an exclusion of a protected class. The court stayed its injunction briefly to allow defendants to seek appellate review.

On March 27, 2025, the D.C. Circuit issued an administrative stay of the preliminary injunction to allow time for further briefing and consideration of the government’s motion for stay pending appeal.

No trial has occurred. The preliminary injunction is under appellate review. The case is notable for its comprehensive factual record, the involvement of decorated service members as plaintiffs, and the court’s finding that the challenged policy is likely unconstitutional under the Fifth Amendment’s equal protection guarantee.
results.45964:
On January 20, 2025, President Trump issued Executive Order No. 14160, which directed federal agencies not to recognize U.S. citizenship for children born in the United States to parents who were either unlawfully present or lawfully present only on a temporary basis, unless at least one parent was a citizen or lawful permanent resident. The States of Washington, Arizona, Illinois, and Oregon filed suit the next day in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington, challenging the Executive Order as unconstitutional and in violation of federal law. They were later joined by a group of noncitizen pregnant women and, after consolidation, by a putative class.

The States alleged that the Executive Order violated the Fourteenth Amendment’s Citizenship Clause, which guarantees citizenship to “all persons born or naturalized in the United States and subject to the jurisdiction thereof,” and also violated Section 1401 of the Immigration and Nationality Act, which closely tracks the constitutional language. The States, represented by their respective Attorneys General, claimed that the Order would directly harm them by causing the loss of federal funds tied to programs such as Medicaid, the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), and foster care, and by imposing immediate and significant administrative burdens to rework eligibility systems for these programs. They also alleged irreparable harm to the rights and welfare of their residents, including children who would be rendered stateless, ineligible for public benefits, or at risk of family separation and deportation.

The States sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including an order barring federal agencies from implementing or enforcing the Executive Order. The district court, presided over by Judge John C. Coughenour, granted a temporary restraining order and, after briefing and argument, entered a preliminary injunction preventing enforcement of the Order nationwide. The district court found that the States had standing due to direct economic and operational harms and concluded that the Order likely violated both the Constitution and the INA.

The Federal Government appealed, arguing that the States lacked standing, that the Order was lawful, and that the injunction was improperly broad. The Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court, holding that the States had standing based on the imminent, concrete loss of federal funds and unrecoverable administrative costs, all caused by the Order’s denial of citizenship to thousands of newborns each month. The Ninth Circuit further held that the Order contradicted the plain text of the Fourteenth Amendment and Supreme Court precedent, which historically and consistently recognized automatic birthright citizenship for nearly all children born on U.S. soil, regardless of their parents’ immigration status, with only narrow exceptions for the children of diplomats, invading armies, or tribal Indians (the latter since superseded by statute).

During the appeal, the Supreme Court reviewed the scope of the injunction, holding that “universal” (nationwide) injunctions are generally improper unless necessary to afford complete relief to the parties. The Supreme Court remanded for determination whether a universal injunction was needed to provide the States full relief. The Ninth Circuit found that, due to interstate movement of affected children and the federal structure of benefits programs, only a universal injunction could prevent the States from suffering the irreparable harms identified.

The court dismissed the Individual Plaintiffs’ claims as moot or as encompassed by a certified nationwide class action in another federal court (in New Hampshire), thus limiting the case to the State Plaintiffs. No trial was held; the case was decided on motions and legal briefing. There was no appointment of a special monitor. The case produced reported opinions at both the district and circuit levels, and the Supreme Court’s order on the scope of injunctions.

In summary, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the preliminary injunction, holding that President Trump’s Executive Order attempting to restrict birthright citizenship was unconstitutional and invalid. The court enjoined the federal government from implementing or enforcing the Order nationwide, as necessary to give the States complete relief, and dismissed the individual claims as duplicative of ongoing class litigation.
results.45965:
This case began on January 21, 2025, when two immigrant rights organizations—CASA, Inc. and the Asylum Seeker Advocacy Project—and several individual plaintiffs, all pregnant women without permanent immigration status, filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland. The suit challenges Executive Order 14,160, issued by President Donald J. Trump on January 20, 2025, which directs federal agencies to stop recognizing birthright citizenship for children born in the United States to noncitizen parents, where the mother is either unlawfully present or only temporarily present and the father is not a U.S. citizen or lawful permanent resident. The complaint was later amended to proceed as a class action on behalf of all affected children and their parents.

The plaintiffs are represented by counsel from CASA, Inc., the Asylum Seeker Advocacy Project, and the Institute for Constitutional Advocacy and Protection at Georgetown Law. Their claims are brought under the Fourteenth Amendment’s Citizenship Clause and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), specifically 8 U.S.C. § 1401(a), arguing that the Executive Order unlawfully denies citizenship guaranteed by the Constitution and statute. The suit seeks declaratory and injunctive relief preventing enforcement of the Executive Order against the class, as well as a declaration of the children’s U.S. citizenship.

The lead judge is Deborah L. Boardman. The defendants are President Trump and the heads of several federal agencies responsible for issuing citizenship documentation and administering immigration and benefit programs, all sued in their official capacities.

Initially, the district court issued a nationwide preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of the Executive Order. The government appealed. The Supreme Court, in Trump v. CASA, Inc., 145 S. Ct. 2540 (2025) (Justice Barrett), held that federal courts lack authority to issue universal injunctions except to provide complete relief to the parties or certified class members. The Supreme Court stayed the broad preliminary injunction but allowed plaintiffs to seek class-wide relief under Rule 23.

Following the Supreme Court’s decision, the plaintiffs filed an amended class action complaint and moved for class certification and a classwide preliminary injunction. The district court certified a nationwide class of children born (or to be born) in the United States after February 19, 2025, whose mothers are either unlawfully present or temporarily present and whose fathers are neither U.S. citizens nor lawful permanent residents. The named class representatives are parents acting as next friends to affected children, some of whom have already given birth. The court appointed counsel from ICAP and ASAP as class counsel.

On August 7, 2025, the court granted a classwide preliminary injunction, enjoining the enforcement of the Executive Order as to the entire certified class. The court found the class met all requirements of Rule 23, including numerosity, commonality, typicality, and adequacy. It held that the plaintiffs were highly likely to succeed on their claims, that the class would face irreparable harm if the Executive Order took effect, and that the balance of equities and the public interest strongly favored an injunction. The injunction prohibits federal agencies from refusing to recognize the citizenship of class members or from denying documentation or benefits on the basis of the Executive Order, pending a final decision on the merits. The court dissolved its earlier individual-based injunction, finding the classwide injunction provided complete relief.

The factual basis of the case centers on the Executive Order’s departure from longstanding constitutional and statutory guarantees of birthright citizenship, which the plaintiffs allege would cause widespread harm and uncertainty to children born on U.S. soil and their families. The court found that the government would not be harmed by an injunction that preserves the status quo of birthright citizenship, and that the Executive Order is likely unconstitutional under binding precedent such as United States v. Wong Kim Ark.

No settlements, monitors, or consent decrees are present in the record, and no trial has occurred. The case is ongoing, with the classwide injunction in place and subject to future appellate review.
results.VR-LA-0120:
On May 19, 2020, several Louisiana voters, a civic engagement organization, and the League of Women Voters Louisiana filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana against the Governor, Secretary of State, and Attorney General of Louisiana. The plaintiffs challenged multiple provisions of Louisiana’s absentee voting laws as applied to the elections scheduled for July, August, November, and December 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic. The case was later consolidated with a similar action brought by the Power Coalition for Equity and Justice, the Louisiana State Conference of the NAACP, and individual voters.

Plaintiffs, represented by the Southern Poverty Law Center and other legal organizations, alleged that Louisiana’s excuse requirement for absentee voting, the witness requirement for absentee ballots, and the lack of a “cure” process for absentee ballots violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution, as well as Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act. They asserted that these provisions forced voters—especially those at heightened risk from COVID-19, those living with vulnerable individuals, and Black voters who disproportionately faced health and socioeconomic burdens—to choose between their health and their right to vote. Plaintiffs also argued that these restrictions unduly burdened the right to vote and amounted to unconstitutional conditions by making the right to vote contingent on risking bodily integrity.

In addition to the individual voters' claims, the organizational plaintiffs asserted that their resources and efforts to promote civic participation were diverted to combat the burdens imposed by the challenged provisions, further supporting their standing. The legal claims sought injunctive and declaratory relief, including an order to enjoin the excuse and witness requirements for absentee voting for all 2020 elections, to require a process for voters to cure ballot deficiencies, and to extend the early voting period.

Defendants, including the Governor, Secretary of State, and Attorney General (the latter also intervening on behalf of the State), moved to dismiss, primarily on jurisdictional grounds. The State argued that plaintiffs lacked Article III standing because any injury was speculative and not traceable to state action, but rather to the external impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The State also raised the Purcell doctrine, urging the court not to order changes to election procedures close to an election, and asserted that the case presented a non-justiciable political question.

On June 22, 2020, the district court granted the defendants’ motion to dismiss for lack of standing, concluding that the plaintiffs' alleged injuries were too speculative and not sufficiently concrete or imminent to confer Article III jurisdiction. The court did not reach the merits or the defendants' additional arguments under Rules 12(b)(6) or 12(b)(7). The original judgment dismissed the case with prejudice, but on the plaintiffs’ motion, the court amended the judgment on June 30, 2020, to clarify that dismissal was without prejudice, allowing for the possibility that the plaintiffs could refile if circumstances changed.

No trial was held, and there was no substantive ruling on the constitutionality of the challenged laws. No injunctive or declaratory relief was granted. The court’s ruling was limited to the threshold jurisdictional issue. There is no indication in the record of any appeal from this judgment.
results.VR-SC-0078:
This case, filed April 22, 2020, in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina (Columbia Division), concerns the impact of South Carolina’s absentee voting laws on the right to vote during the COVID-19 pandemic. The plaintiffs—consisting of individual voters at high risk for COVID-19 complications, a nonprofit organization (The Family Unit, Inc.), and later the South Carolina State Conference of the NAACP—challenged two absentee voting requirements: (1) the Excuse Requirement, which limits eligibility for absentee voting to specific statutory categories (S.C. Code Ann. § 7-15-320), and (2) the Witness Requirement, which mandates that an absentee ballot envelope be signed by a third-party witness (S.C. Code Ann. § 7-15-220).

The defendants are members and the Executive Director of the South Carolina State Election Commission, sued in their official capacities, and the Governor of South Carolina. The South Carolina Republican Party, as well as legislative leaders (the Speaker of the House and President of the Senate), intervened in the case. Plaintiffs were represented by the ACLU and NAACP Legal Defense Fund, among others; the defendants by private counsel and the State Attorney General.

The plaintiffs alleged that, amid the COVID-19 pandemic and related public health orders, these requirements forced voters—particularly those who are elderly, have disabilities, or are Black—into an untenable choice between their health and their right to vote, violating the First and Fourteenth Amendments, Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). Plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief, including an order permitting all voters to cast absentee ballots and eliminating the witness requirement for the duration of the pandemic.

Shortly after the suit was filed, the South Carolina legislature enacted a temporary change (S.C. Act 133, signed May 13, 2020), allowing all voters to cast absentee ballots in the June 2020 primary and runoff elections due to the state of emergency. This mooted the challenge to the Excuse Requirement for the June elections, but not for later elections, including the November general election. The Witness Requirement, however, remained in force.

On May 25, 2020, Judge J. Michelle Childs issued a preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of the Witness Requirement for the June 2020 primary and runoff elections, finding that, under pandemic conditions, it likely imposed a severe burden on the right to vote that outweighed the state’s interests. The court ordered election officials to inform voters of the suspension of the witness rule for those elections. The court declined to enjoin the Excuse Requirement for elections beyond June 2020 at that time due to legislative action and procedural circumstances.

After the June primaries, the temporary legislative expansion of absentee eligibility expired. Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint seeking permanent injunctive relief against both requirements for the November 2020 election and beyond, citing ongoing COVID-19 risks. The court consolidated related cases and permitted additional parties, including the legislative leaders, to intervene.

The state and intervenors moved for summary judgment, arguing plaintiffs lacked standing, that the requirements were reasonable, nondiscriminatory, and justified by state interests in election integrity and fraud prevention, and that no evidence showed a disparate impact on Black voters or voters with disabilities. They also cited legislative authority over election law under the South Carolina Constitution.

Discovery revealed that, during the June 2020 primaries, most voters continued to vote in person, and no COVID-19 outbreaks were traced to polling places. Plaintiffs’ depositions showed that those at high risk often could obtain a witness signature (e.g., from a housekeeper or family member), and organizational plaintiffs had difficulty identifying specific members unable to vote absentee due to the requirements.

As the federal case neared trial in September 2020, the court stayed proceedings after granting a similar preliminary injunction against the Witness Requirement in a related case (Middleton v. Andino), covering the November 2020 general election. The stay order held all motions and the trial in abeyance, pending further developments in the pandemic and legislative action. The court instructed plaintiffs to move to lift the stay if the situation changed before future statewide elections.

Throughout the case, the court was presided over by Judge J. Michelle Childs. The parties were represented by private and nonprofit counsel, with participation by the United States (as amicus), the State Attorney General, and the Protection and Advocacy for People with Disabilities, Inc. (as amicus). The case was not a class action. No court-appointed monitor was involved. The court issued no final judgment or permanent injunction on the merits as of the last available filings.

**Key Information Checklist Summary:**

- **Filing Date:** April 22, 2020
- **Parties:** Individual voters at high risk for COVID-19, The Family Unit, Inc., and SC State Conference of the NAACP; against the Executive Director and members of the South Carolina State Election Commission and the Governor (official capacity)
- **Class Action:** No
- **Type of Counsel:** Private, ACLU, NAACP LDF, Willkie Farr, and others
- **Cause of Action:** 42 U.S.C. § 1983; Voting Rights Act § 2; Americans with Disabilities Act, Title II
- **Statutory/Constitutional Basis:** First and Fourteenth Amendments (right to vote), Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, Title II of the ADA
- **Remedy Sought:** Declaratory and injunctive relief (eliminate Excuse and Witness Requirements during pandemic)
- **Judge:** Judge J. Michelle Childs
- **Related Cases:** Middleton v. Andino (3:20-cv-01730-JMC)
- **Important Filings:** Motions for preliminary injunction and summary judgment; court grant of preliminary injunction (May 25, 2020) against Witness Requirement for June primaries; stay order (September 18, 2020)
- **Court Rulings:** Preliminary injunction granted as to Witness Requirement for June 2020 elections; case stayed before trial for subsequent elections
- **Trials:** None held; trial stayed
- **Appeals:** Not indicated in the record provided
- **Significant Terms of Decrees/Orders:** Temporary suspension of witness requirement for June 2020 primaries; no permanent relief entered
- **Duration of Decrees:** Preliminary injunction limited to June 2020 primaries and runoffs; stay in effect as of September 2020
- **Monitoring/Settlement:** No monitor, no settlement
- **Factual Basis:** COVID-19 pandemic, public health orders, risk to high-risk voters, alleged disparate impact on Black voters and people with disabilities, legislative context, and absentee voting practices in South Carolina
results.JC-MD-0017:
On April 21, 2020, a group of pretrial and post-conviction detainees, including Keith Seth, David Smith, Mario Burch, and individuals proceeding pseudonymously as John Does 1–5, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against Mary Lou McDonough, Director of the Prince George’s County Department of Corrections, in her official capacity. The plaintiffs were represented by Civil Rights Corps and WilmerHale attorneys. They brought the suit on behalf of all individuals detained at the Prince George’s County Jail, including a subclass of those medically vulnerable to COVID-19 due to age or underlying health conditions.

The case arose during the initial months of the COVID-19 pandemic. Plaintiffs alleged that the Jail was experiencing an uncontrolled outbreak and had failed to follow CDC and public health guidance to prevent and treat COVID-19 among detainees. They claimed detainees did not have adequate access to soap, cleaning supplies, or information about COVID-19, and that those with symptoms or medically vulnerable status received inadequate or delayed medical care. Plaintiffs also challenged the Jail’s policy of detaining COVID-positive individuals who were otherwise legally entitled to release, and alleged that the Jail was subjecting all detainees to indefinite, near-solitary lockdown conditions without procedural protections or adequate mental health care.

The legal claims were brought under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 for violations of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments (for both conditions of confinement and overdetention), and under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 for habeas relief for the medically vulnerable subclass. The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief requiring the Jail to implement CDC-recommended procedures to safeguard detainees’ health, as well as immediate release or transfer to home detention for members of the medically vulnerable subclass.

The case was assigned to Judge Paula Xinis. Plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order (TRO) and preliminary injunction. The Court held expedited proceedings, appointing an independent infectious disease expert (Dr. Carlos Franco-Paredes) under Federal Rule of Evidence 706 to inspect the jail and report on its COVID-19 response.

On May 21, 2020, after reviewing declarations, expert reports, and the parties’ submissions, the Court found that the Jail had experienced a significant outbreak, had only limited testing, lacked a systematic plan for isolating and treating COVID-19-positive or medically vulnerable detainees, and that many detainees faced delayed or inadequate medical responses. The Court concluded that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment claims regarding jail conditions, and that the risk of serious illness or death constituted irreparable harm. The Court issued a TRO requiring the Jail to file comprehensive written plans addressing the identification and protection of high-risk detainees, staff training, testing protocols, and continued provision of hygiene and social distancing measures, among other requirements. The Court denied immediate classwide release or transfer, holding that such relief would require further proceedings and was subject to the Prison Litigation Reform Act (PLRA) limitations.

The Jail filed written plans as ordered. Plaintiffs and Defendant continued to dispute whether the Jail’s practices and plans satisfied constitutional standards, particularly with respect to ongoing lockdown conditions and procedural protections for detainees. The TRO was later permitted to expire without conversion to a preliminary injunction, and the Court denied further preliminary relief.

The case proceeded in discovery, with the Court hearing additional motions to dismiss by the Defendant, who argued that the claims were moot for released plaintiffs, that plaintiffs failed to exhaust administrative remedies, and that the amended complaint failed to state claims for relief. Plaintiffs opposed, maintaining that class claims remained viable and that the PLRA’s exhaustion requirement did not apply due to the unavailability of meaningful grievance procedures.

Separately, the parties engaged in settlement discussions with Magistrate Judge Timothy J. Sullivan. As of early 2021, the case was stayed pending further settlement efforts. No final judgment, class certification, or merits ruling on the amended complaint has yet been entered.

**Key Information Checklist:**

- **Filing Date:** April 21, 2020 (original complaint); amended complaint filed July 3, 2020.
- **Parties:** Plaintiffs are pretrial and post-conviction detainees at the Prince George’s County Jail (including a medically vulnerable subclass); Defendant is Mary Lou McDonough, Director of the Prince George’s County Department of Corrections, sued in her official capacity.
- **Class Action:** Yes; plaintiffs sought certification for all current and future detainees and a medically vulnerable subclass.
- **Type of Counsel:** Civil Rights Corps (private, public interest firm) and WilmerHale (pro bono).
- **Cause of Action:** 42 U.S.C. § 1983; 28 U.S.C. § 2241 (habeas); Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment constitutional claims.
- **Statutory/Constitutional Basis:** Eighth Amendment (cruel and unusual punishment); Fourteenth Amendment (due process, equal protection); Section 1983; Section 2241.
- **Remedy Sought:** Declaratory and injunctive relief (including compliance with CDC guidelines, improved medical care, and procedural protections), release or transfer for medically vulnerable subclass, and an end to overdetention of COVID-positive detainees entitled to release.
- **Judge:** Judge Paula Xinis.
- **Consolidated/Related Cases:** None noted.
- **Important Filings:** TRO and preliminary injunction motions, extensive briefing, expert reports, amended complaint, motions to dismiss, and summary judgment.
- **Court Rulings:** TRO granted in part (May 21, 2020), requiring plans for COVID-19 response; preliminary injunction denied; other motions to dismiss and for summary judgment pending; case stayed for settlement.
- **Trials:** None to date.
- **Appeals:** Defendant filed an interlocutory appeal of the TRO, which was dismissed after the TRO expired.
- **Decrees/Orders:** TRO required written plans for identification, monitoring, and protection of high-risk detainees, hygiene, testing, and staff training.
- **Settlements:** No final settlement entered; case stayed for ongoing discussions.
- **Monitoring:** Dr. Carlos Franco-Paredes appointed as independent expert; made site visit and reported to the Court.
- **Factual Basis:** Plaintiffs alleged uncontrolled COVID-19 outbreak, lack of CDC-compliant measures, inadequate hygiene and medical care, overdetention of COVID-positive individuals, and prolonged, indefinite lockdown conditions amounting to solitary confinement without procedural protections.
- **Duration/Status:** Case pending; class certification and merits not finally resolved as of stay for settlement negotiations.
results.IM-FL-0029:
On April 13, 2020, a group of civil immigration detainees held by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) at three South Florida facilities—the Krome Service Processing Center, Broward Transitional Center, and Glades County Detention Center—filed a class action in the Southern District of Florida. The lawsuit was pursued by legal services organizations and private counsel. The detainees, representing themselves and others similarly situated, sought emergency injunctive and declaratory relief, asserting that the conditions of their confinement during the COVID-19 pandemic placed them at imminent risk of serious illness or death.

The plaintiffs alleged that ICE’s practices at these facilities did not comply with CDC guidelines, ICE’s own Pandemic Response Requirements, or applicable detention standards. They claimed that social distancing was impossible, hygiene and cleaning supplies were inadequate, and cohorting and transfer practices heightened rather than mitigated the risk of COVID-19 transmission. The plaintiffs asserted that these failures amounted to violations of their Fifth Amendment due process rights and, by analogy, Eighth Amendment protections against cruel and unusual punishment, and also brought related claims under the Accardi doctrine for failure to follow government regulations.

The case was assigned to Judge Marcia G. Cooke, with Magistrate Judge Jonathan Goodman handling pretrial matters. Plaintiffs filed for a temporary restraining order (TRO) and preliminary injunction. After an emergency hearing, the court issued a TRO and later a preliminary injunction. The court found, based on the evidence and witness testimony, that ICE had failed to implement adequate COVID-19 safety measures and showed deliberate indifference to the detainees’ safety. The orders required ICE to comply with CDC and its own guidelines, provide sufficient masks and hygiene supplies, educate detainees on COVID-19, limit transfers to those with negative COVID-19 tests, and maintain population levels consistent with public health guidance (generally not exceeding 75% of capacity).

The case was certified as a class action under Rule 23(b)(2), with the class defined as all current and future civil immigration detainees held at the three South Florida facilities. The court retained jurisdiction over transferred class members and appointed a special master to monitor compliance. The special master conducted facility inspections and reported that, while ICE had made some improvements, social distancing and other core preventive measures remained insufficient given the structure and operation of the facilities.

Throughout the litigation, the court issued numerous orders enforcing the preliminary injunction, compelling ICE to comply with COVID-19 protocols, and ordering regular reporting. The parties engaged in extensive factual discovery, including depositions and expert reports.

On June 28, 2021, the parties reached a court-enforced class settlement. Under the agreement, ICE would maintain COVID-19 safety protocols at the three facilities, including full compliance with ICE and CDC guidelines, provision of COVID-19 and influenza vaccines at no cost to detainees, regular testing and isolation practices, unrestricted access to hygiene supplies, adequate social distancing where feasible, education on COVID-19, and continued population controls. The agreement also required ICE to log and report cleaning and supply distribution, ensure mask distribution, and limit transfers to those testing negative for COVID-19. The settlement allowed class members to pursue individual habeas claims for release, provided for court enforcement of the agreement, and required regular reporting for a minimum of six months or until all detainees had access to vaccination.

The court retained jurisdiction to enforce the settlement, and the case resolved without a trial or monetary damages. The settlement marked the end of the class-wide litigation concerning COVID-19 safety in ICE detention in South Florida during the pandemic.
